summary: When Tim Lake (Domhnall Gleeson) is 21, his father (Bill Nighy) tells him a secret: The men in their family can travel through time. Although he can't change history, Tim resolves to improve his life by getting a girlfriend. He meets Mary (Rachel McAdams), falls in love and finally wins her heart via time-travel and a little cunning. However, as his unusual life progresses, Tim finds that his special ability can't shield him and those he loves from the problems of ordinary life.

reviews.content: I'm speechless about this movie. Perfect. It's one of my favorites, I could watch it a hundred times without get sick of it.
My favorite movie. Everything is perfect.
Best feel-good love story I've seen !! Will warm your heart and sends some very valuable life messages.
Special Effects: 1,0/Sound Effects: 1,0/Acting: 1,0/Story: 2,0

Only reason I didn't give it a perfect score is because of a few inconsistencies in the time travel plot. Other than that this is a pure feel good movie even though it leaves me crying every time without fail and I am not cryer
Great movie. Very heart warming. Great acting, cinematography, plot, and storyline. Although it was two hours long, it was very entertaining from start till finish. Well done.

The first thing to mention about this movie is its excellent cinematography and such. Those things aren't what makes this a great movie though! It has great pacing for being two hours, a touching story, and it doesn't even screw up time travel! It has the most simple time rules and it doesn't try to do too much with them, very enjoyable and easy to follow. What is especially great about this movie, is its not so subtle, yet subtle lessons and messages about life. Such as sacrificing your own happiness for others, taking chances, cherishing every moment you're given and living life to it's fullest. Now I'm certain there are more lessons to be learned in there but these are what really stick out. This is a well done,  excellent film, with a lot of heart and meaning behind it.
Although the beginning is "weird" with the theme of time travel, this film is worth every minute spent. You can try but you won't be able to hold back the tears

This is my and my husbands favorite movie. We watch it at least once a year. Rachel McAdams and Domhall Gleeson are wonderful together. There is a lovely father/ son story, with Bill Nighy. Tom Hollander is a family friend, roommate and an hillarious cumudgeon. Lindsay Duncan plays is a lovable, honest mom. Always a great watch.

I just can watch it over and over again! Somehow this movie makes me feel warm in my heart from your love. And the movie teaches you to live your life day by day mindful and thankful. If we overlook the fact that Tim can travel back in time(which is cheating and unreal) you will enjoy watching this!

I can't believe the same team that made Notting Hill and Love, Actually made this film. It's so much better. Simultaneously funny and deep, with my favorite Bill Nighy performance. All brilliantly acted and emotionally resonant. Tom Hollander is a fantastic asshole friend.

In fact, the only thing keeping it (imo) from a top score was that fact that I felt they stretched the film a bit and dropping one of the subplots would probably have made it a bit more enjoyable overall.  Still, absolutely worth checking out.

Best movie I've seen in quite awhile. The acting is solid, but not great by most of the actors, but Rachel McAdams was outstanding.  There were enough illogical inconsistencies in the time travel aspect that anyone who thinks of it primarily as science fiction will be annoyed.  

The father son relation ship of Tim and James, and then Tim and his children resonates in an authentic and thought provoking way for any parent. that alone is enough to want to watch this film, but the romantic comedy part of it was pleasant without being over sweet. It's incredible that they made such an interesting movie despite mostly mediocre acting and a far fetched plot gimmick. 

But the movie worked. It didn't take itself too seriously, and wasn't completely goofy either. It was a nice balance and something that I was surprised to see was made 9 years ago.

My wife didn't like it, she heard "time travel" and immediately dismissed it as sci fi and stopped paying attention. Her loss. Don't miss an opportunity to see this gem because you dismiss "About Time" as science fiction, because it isn't. The time travel think is just a plot device.

I wasn't much impressed with this film. Its an easy enough watch and the time element intrigued me but it didn't particularly stand out. I liked 'Love Actually' but this didn't really compare. I thought Bill Nighy did alright as the father. Of course its quite cheesy, a Richard Curtis rom com type drama will always tend to be cheesy I imagine but its one of those films that I found myself not feeling entirely bothered about what had happened toward the end. Perhaps I wasn't paying full attention but it didn't really engross me enough to feel invested in it, hence my low-ish rate. I think some people will enjoy this but it won't appeal to all. I wouldn't especially recommend it as such, no but there again, if your a fan of this type of film then it may be worth having a look at some point, otherwise I wouldn't bother.

About Time is a romantic comedy that abides themes such as living in the present. It is a beautiful movie that tells us so much about life and living every day to the fullest. This movie is not only about a love story, but more about the challenges of life and how important it is to show love to our family and the people around us at every given opportunity, without waiting before it's too late. It tells a lot about the son and father relationship, and it takes us to stir emotions with the most meaningful ping pong game, giving a sense of how little moments in life can mean a lot. About Time makes us reflect on life and how we are using our time, makes us question how we are showing love towards the ones we love, how we are making others' day better, etc. It shows how important is the way we approach our day, even simplest as it can be. Tim's father gives him the "big secret" on using this gift that they have. Still, Tim goes a little farther in learning about this, saying how he just tried to live every day as he would travel back to this one day, just to enjoy it, not needing to use his extraordinary gift at all.
  About Time is a well-filmed movie that shows the reality of life. It has a story lesson and wants the audience to ponder about life. The casting is good, and although the authors did a good job, my favorite actor in this movie was Bill Nighy, who played the father. The film has a good intention, but I feel it lacks many things and could have improvements. First, the script uses some inappropriate language, which I would not recommend for a younger audience. Second, the movie repeatedly repeats many scenes because of the time-traveling, making the film seem long. Even if the director Richard Curtis wanted the film to have more of day-to-day life, it has a lot of unnecessary scenes, making the movie a little dull. Despite this criticism, this movie has a lot of sweet and funny scenes and has a story to learn from it. However, I would say it's not the best movie out there. I do recommend this movie, but do not expect something fantastic out of it. I would give it 3/5 stars.

It's worth a watch. About Time goes for relatable life themes surrounding love, family, and more, but it doesn't quite stick the landing. The reliance on time travel was not executed well enough to serve its purpose of carrying the movie. Pacing was very awkward.

"Now, son - you can only travel back in time on your own timeline. You can only go back to places you were present - you can't kill Hitler or shag Helen of Troy."

10 minutes later our valiant hero is trying to rewrite history by changing events during the performance of a play he didn't attend. We know that this can't have been on his original timeline, since Mary's number is no longer in his phone. 
True, he's learned the most difficult lesson about tinkering with things beyond his ken, which is "changing the past is like throwing a pebble into a pool - the ripples expand outwards until they reach the shore." Those of us who can travel in time know this all too well, and most of the time the effects are undesirable, so even though we can, we don't.

Enhanced with endearing characters including Bill Nighy as the Dad who shares great insights in life and Lydia Wilson as the spritely and enchanting sister, the story is a call to action for us to reflect and embrace life to the fullest.

This is my all time favourite film. It's not a big blockbuster or full of visual spectacles but what it does have is; a talented cast, a unique story, witty and subtle humour, and a beautiful message. I watch this movie whenever I need a pick me up or a stern reminder that I have a very blessed life and I should be more grateful for it. The message of the film teaches it's audience that what we think will make us happy stops us from stopping and smelling the roses of our already charmed life. Life is never easy but it is beautiful if one could learn to see the beauty in it. 
The love story in this film is a beautiful love story. It's not a traditional Hollywood love story because it lacks all of the overused tropes like love triangles, ultimatums, forbidden love, infidelity, passionate love affairs, or anything like that. It's just two people who are perfectly suited for one another, falling in love, and falling more in love and gaining more respect for each other as the years goes on. This is the love story we should all want in our real lives and it's beautiful to see it on film. 
I never wanted the story to end and to say goodbye to these characters. 
This will be my favourite movie for years to come as it has been since its release.

To be honest I find this movie kind of hilarious. Like I enjoy it. But its just so... privileged. The film itself I mean. And the protagonist. Like what is this movie but a young man's search for happiness and an understanding of the meaning of life and what's important? But frankly... what a cushy path this young man walks. Born to every advantage most people will never benefit from: a wonderful childhood in a peaceful home by the beach, loving, caring parents, money, money, money, guidance to future success and happiness, whiteness, and of course, time travel. 

And this is supposed to be enlightening? This is supposed to be sincere and endearing? I've never seen an easier path walked. And it calls into question the wisdom earned. "Oh everything is just beautiful and wonderful, if you only pay attention!" Not bad advice in and of itself. But it goes thoroughly unchallenged in this film as the protagonist bounces around from one windfall to the next. Oh my god, my beloved father is dying, this will surely challenge me. Yes, it will, but it's just so... easy, on the face of it. Your relationship to your father is in the best possible shape it could ever be in, and he has lived several, SEVERAL, lifetimes already as he goes back to relive his life again and again. 

It just doesn't feel earned. Have a challenging relationship. Have a challenge anywhere, be less than perfect. And see how your thesis stands up to it.
An incredible and moving film! Amazing acting and very moving. A must see. It's funny, sad and makes you smile with joy and I cannot express how lovely this film was

The extraordinary chemistry between McAdams and Gleeson is just as remarkable as the message of this film, which is -of course- about time or, to be clearer, about letting time going by and enjoying it, with this its ebbs and flows, where anything that could happen will.. or  maybe not. However, we must enjoy every single day as it was the last one. 
As in horror, in the huge rom-com field is really hard to find a good romantic comedy, that is why this movie feels even more special, because it's fresh in an industry where stories lots of times are rotten, soulful in a time where everything is done with economic intentions and in a loveless way, and at parts will get you laughing your ass off for its clever script.

This thought-provoking movie by Richard Curtis (who brought us "Four Weddings And A Funeral" and "Love Actually") manages to blend together the themes of a romantic dramedy (which borders more on the family drama side) and time-travel (along similar lines as "Groundhog Day"). Throughout the film, the occasional plot-hole is evident, although that is forgivable due to there being the right balance of well-timed wit and sentiment the whole way through. This is an interesting movie - it doesn't go the way you think it will. I like that it doesn't spend the whole movie trying to make you guess whether Tim and Mary will end up together. About Time is basically a story on how one should cherish every moment in life and take notice of all the beautiful things around you. It's mostly a feel good story. It tries to cover the darker stages in life as well, and how the character with his time travelling powers still have to go through them, but as negative as reality sometimes gets for most, it never becomes. 

And this is fine in my opinion. A movie doesn't have to fully cover reality. Apart from the time of movie About Time is, it's also an attempt to think about what possibilities there are if one had this specific type of time travelling power. 

The movie tells a simple but original story, well thought through, fun and told in a beautiful way. It looks and feels different somehow, maybe because of the British setting. The interesting take in my opinion is that apart from the ability to travel through time, they attempt to keep everything else realistic.

The atmosphere keeps mostly the same. There are some quite funny moments, but About Time is not a movie that's intended to make it's audience roll out of their chairs laughing.

There are some insights on life shared, that as a viewer I felt one should take to heart, but it never gets overly idealistic or even preachy. They even put it in perspective themselves since the main character makes an alternative choice, which I found pretty interesting.

I felt for the characters involved, who come over als believable. As a viewer, you don't get drawn in with them though. The only criticism I can think of is a little lack of character development. But I'm not sure if I needed this for the story the movie makers are trying to tell.

Yes, scifi-nerds will find problems in the way time traveling is implemented since the story ignores a lot of related problems. But it's a feel good movie, which doesn't need to get every philosophical point correct.
Perfect! It's my favorite movie!

What happens when you take the ability to travel back in time like Edge of Tomorrow or the ability to relive the same day like Groundhog's Day and add an uninspired loser who only wants to be loved like 500 Days of Summer... what do you get? An boring, hackneyed production written and directed by someone who's satisfyied with tried-and-true cliches: first kiss, first time in bed, weddings, births... blah, blah, blah.

While the acting is okay - the story is quite atrocious. On his 21st birthday, Tim (Gleeson) learns that he can travel back to anyday he can remember just because he can. So what does Tim choose to do with this extraordinary gift? Play the same days over to allow him to win over Mary (McAdams) by telling her what she wants to hear. That's essentially the entire movie and spoilers!

The story alludes to Tim, as a lawyer, uses this to win all his cases - and occasionally help others... but OMG can writer/director, Curtis really not find anything more creative for Tim to do? 20 years earlier, Ramis gave us a hundred different things that someone can do if they knew they could relive the same day over. Curtis could only think of three.... showing a true lack of creativity or imagination.

If you like predictable, Hallmark-ish, sappy romantic comedies -- than you just may like About Time. But if you expect more from today's movies, than you can more definitely can do better.

Normally I'm wary of romcoms. But this movie genuinely surprised me. About Time is a rom-com that asks the simple question "if you had the ability to time travel, what would you do?" This simple premise is given with no complex explanation and the rest of the story follows. The movie starts off a bit cheesy and predictable but goes through a series of twists and turns. There's a ton of real heartfelt moments that the main character, Tim Lake (Domhnall Gleeson) shares with every major character of the film. Domhnall Gleeson also does a convincing role as the awkward English boy a bit too well. Bill Nighy does an above-and-beyond performance as a Dad and the father-son chemistry with Domhnall feels genuine. Themes covered in this film showcase the value of relationships in one's life and how major decisions can shift the direction of one's life. The film is about two hours but it feels much longer than that, in a good way. This film is sentimental and beautiful. I normally don't do sentimental films, but this film had me feeling some type of way. 5/5. Be warned, you may find yourself hiding in your closet, clenching your first, trying to go back in time. It's definitely worth a watch with a loved one.

People say this is a romantic comedy but I think About Time is more a coming of age tale - how your family affects who you become. The relationship between Tim, Domhnall Gleeson and his father, Bill Nighy, is the central relationship of the film. Tim's wife, Rachel McAdams, doesn't really have enough personality of her own but he loves her for orbiting around him. You also can't really think about the central plot device, time travel, in any intermediate way. I often thought, "but, how?", "but, why?", "but... I thought...?" about Tim's various jumps and they often broke the rules set forth in the film - which for some reason his father doesn't tell him about immediately? It might seem like I didn't like About Time, but I did, because for every twee, contrived classic Richard Curtis moment, there were lovely, hopeful, inspiring, classic Richard Curtis moments.

Not a terrible romantic comedy.  Domhall Gleeson plays an awkward 21-yr old law apprentice in London, when he learns from his father (Bill Nighy) that all of the men in his family have an extraordinary talent: time travel.  There are of course limits:  you can only travel within your lifetime, and only into the past, and if you travel earlier than when your offspring is conceived, your offspring from the future of that point will be a different person.  That last point is critical, because Tim (Gleeson) recognizes that once his 3rd child is conceived, he can never travel back to revisit his father, who is now deceased, without changing his child.  It's little details like that which make time-travel movies so much fun.  But Richard Curtis violates his own rules after he creates them, which causes a lot of confusion.  Clearly, if you can enjoy the characters on-screen without realizing the inconsistencies in the narration, you'll enjoy the film.  Nighy steals every scene he's in, he is so much fun to watch.  Rachel McAdams is Gleeson's eventual wife (after several meet-cute redo's) and McAdams is given virtually no character development to work with.  She's on-screen to smile and be reactionary to Gleeson's awkwardness.  She doesn't even attempt a British accent, even though everyone else in the cast is British-born.  This shortcoming is explained as being an American character in an essentially British film.  Worth the watch if you enjoy the actors; just don't try to think too hard about it.

At the age of 21, Tim Lake (Domhnall Gleeson) discovers he can travel in time... The night after another unsatisfactory New Year party, Tim's father (Bill Nighy) tells his son that the men in his family have always had the ability to travel through time. Tim can't change history, but he can change what happens and has happened in his own life-so he decides to make his world a better place...by getting a girlfriend. Sadly, that turns out not to be as easy as you might think. Moving from the Cornwall coast to London to train as a lawyer, Tim finally meets the beautiful but insecure Mary (Rachel McAdams). They fall in love, then an unfortunate time-travel incident means he's never met her at all. So they meet for the first time again-and again-but finally, after a lot of cunning time-traveling, he wins her heart. Tim then uses his power to create the perfect romantic proposal, to save his wedding from the worst best-man speeches, to save his best friend from professional disaster and to get his pregnant wife to the hospital in time for the birth of their daughter, despite a nasty traffic jam outside Abbey Road. But as his unusual life progresses, Tim finds out that his unique gift can't save him from the sorrows and ups and downs that affect all families, everywhere. There are great limits to what time travel can achieve, and it can be dangerous too...

"About Time" received mostly positive reviews from critics. Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Beautifully filmed and unabashedly sincere, About Time finds director Richard Curtis at his most sentimental." Catherine Shoard of The Guardian compared the film to Groundhog Day noting it "is about as close to home as a homage can get without calling in the copyright team" and describes Domhnall Gleeson as a "ginger Hugh Grant", which "at first, is unnerving; as About Time marches on, Gleeson's innate charm gleams through and this weird disconnection becomes quite compelling." Shoard gave the film 2 stars out of 5. Robbie Collin of The Daily Telegraph praised the comic timing of McAdams and Gleeson, but criticised the film, comparing it to a quilt, calling it "soft, frayed at the edges, and oh so comfortable" and gives it a score of 3 stars out of 5. Leslie Felperin of Variety magazine called the film "reassuringly bland" and says there is sense of déjà vu especially for anyone who has seen The Time Traveler's Wife also co-starring McAdams. Unlike that film she has no knowledge of his powers, resulting in a "fundamental lack of honesty in their relationship". Felperin noted British reverse snobbery would put many off this and other Curtis films, but that this would be less of a problem among American Anglophiles and those willing to suspend disbelief, taking the characters as British "versions of Woody Allen's Manhattanites (but with less angst)". Felperin praised the chemistry of the leading couple "that keeps the film aloft" and the supporting cast, while also criticising the stock characters as being too familiar. The film became a surprise hit in South Korea, where it was watched by more than 3 million people, one of the highest numbers among the foreign romantic comedy movies released in Korea.

The premise of the story is just seriously wishy washy, pretentiously romcomy and way too jumpy in the storyline. It´s actually only in the end of the film when Nighy´s character has passed away things become emotionally moving. And by then it´s too late to get emotionally engaged in the film. I think the cast is solid in general, Bill Nighy is always good and that needs to be mentioned. But, the characters leave a lot to wish for. About Time is one of my favourite guilty pleasure movies that I just love to watch over and over and just enjoy the story of love I'm being told. I know this movie isn't perfect so it shouldn't really be a 5 star movie but it's one of my favorites and I just love everything about it so to me it is a 5 star movie. This movie is a perfect combination of a romantic drama with a little bit of a science fiction twist and the mixture is amazing together in this film. The plot is so brilliant and has some funny moments and some very sad tear jerking moments. It engaged me throughout the whole journey and I felt the connections that the characters in the movie felt it was a magical experience. The actors/actresses did a fantastic job as well Domhnall Gleeson gives a performance I loved and really connected with him and felt like you were in his shoes making certain life changing decisions, but the real star of the movie is Rachel McAdams she was amazing in this movie and in my opinion probably her best performance of her career. She was a great choice as the little insecure girl at the beginning falling in love with Tim.  Some more were Bill Nighy who provided some comedy relief in certain parts of the movie, also Lydia Wilson played Kit Kat very well for an actor I'm not very familiar with. The themes in this movie are also very important and work well with the movie structure. So About Time is an emotional journey of plenty ups and downs that really makes the audience connect with the story and the characters. The plot is outstandingly written, the actors did a fantastic job and the tone shifts are on point and really captures the right emotion for every single scene. In my eyes this is a perfect movie.

A beautiful movie on every level you can think of. The characters are funny and natural and the music and photography/cinematographu is stunning. The ending is a bit overly sentimental in it's message, but I forgive it. I forgive everything.

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) Greg, it s about time we reviewed About Time.

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) And there s no time like the present! Let s recap.

SCOTT: We meet our hero, an Englishman named Tim (Domhnall Gleeson), who appears to be an ordinary, awkward 21-year-old until one day his father (Bill Nighy) tells him the big family secret: All the men in the family have the ability to go back in time. Tim decides to use this power to acquire the one thing that has always eluded him, namely, a girlfriend. He meets a wonderful American girl named Mary (Rachel McAdams), and after several time-travel trips (needed to erase his mistakes) he is able to win her heart.

GREG: Scott, this is a nice, warm love story in the same category as  Notting Hill  or  Love, Actually  (all by the same writer / director Richard Curtis). Tim meets Mary at a dinner party and successfully gets her number.  But then he decides to travel back in time to fix a play by his father s playwright-friend Harry. When he does, he alters the events that lead up to meeting Mary. He then has to wait for Mary at a Kate Moss exhibit and when he does, he learns that she has a new boyfriend. So, he goes back in time and intercepts Mary before she meets the opposition. He then tries and tries again, working on his approach until he perfects it. She falls for him a second time.

SCOTT: I agree that About Time is the sweetest, most endearing love story of the year. It reminds me of a 2006 Sandra Bullock film called The Lake House in that it is a romantic tale that incorporates elements of time travel. About Time is a stronger movie than The Lake House largely due to the remarkable performance of Domhnall Gleeson, who plays the role of a sweet, humble, love-starved man to perfection. We have a terrific ensemble performance here, with individually great actors forming a whole that exceeds its parts. Bill Nighy strikes just the right notes as the loveable, playful dad. Tim s sister Lydia (Lydia Wilson) is wacky, dysfunctional, but equally loveable. We even want to give the demented uncle (Richard Cordery) a big bear hug. And of course Rachel McAdams steals our hearts with her warm portrayal of a woman who is one of the few souls worthy of Tim s big heart. This movie exudes charm from start to finish.

GREG: I thought About Time reminded me of Groundhog Day - one of your favorite movies, Scott. In it Bill Murray trips through time repeating the day over and over again trying to win the heart of the beautiful Andie McDowell. About Time is a wonderful hero s journey. Tim starts out as an ordinary young man who wants to win the heart of a young lady. He s given a special power from his mentor-dad. He then spends the summer trying to make it with a pretty girl, only to learn that even with time travel you cannot force someone to love you. Then he gets a new goal - to win the love of Mary. Things are going pretty well as he builds a relationship with his new love when something happens that turns his life upside down. He must then regroup and come up with a plan for making things right. He learns a life lesson that we can all take home. It s a complete mythological story in a modern setting.

SCOTT: If I had to pick some nits, the rules of the time-travel superpower seem like rather arbitrary plot devices meant to manipulate our emotions. Also, About Time offers a confused message about how to live one s life. As we ve mentioned, there are scenes where Tim keeps repeating a day until he is able to produce just the right events to make a relationship with his future wife possible. The lesson appears to be that we should make strong efforts to impose our will on a situation rather than allow the events in our lives to unfold naturally. Yet there s another scene that suggests the opposite lesson. In this scene, natural circumstances lead Tim to encounter a woman named Charlotte whom he is trying to avoid. Even his time travel powers cannot prevent this encounter, although he tries using them anyway. It s clear that Tim s character needs to be tested by this encounter, and he passes the test, allowing him to transform as a character. This scene suggests that we should accept things that are either meant to happen or meant not to happen.

GREG: I think that time travel is a superpower that everyone wants because we all feel regret. How often have you gone home after a party and wished you had said something slightly more clever to your boss - or some other person you wanted to impress? Time travel gives our hero (and therefore ourselves) the ability to go back and try it again (and again) until we get it right. And our hero Tim is a true virtuous hero as he doesn t try to gain fame or fortune for himself. He just wants to win the heart of a pretty girl. And remember, the writer establishes early in the film that try as you might, even time travel cannot make someone love you. They have to have it in them to begin with. And so Tim is really just getting what is rightfully his.

SCOTT: I thoroughly enjoyed About Time from start to finish. The movie offers up a truly moving love story, not just between a man and a woman, but between a man and his father as well. There aren t many movies that leave me near tears at the end, but About Time left me with a lump in my throat the size of Tim s enormous heart. This film is the best love story in the movies in the past five years. I happily give About Time 4 Reels out of 5. As you ve noted, Greg, we have a wonderful hero transformation here, as Tim learns that you don t have to repeat a day to improve upon it -- you can simply allow it to unfold with all its flawed beauty permanently etched in time and with no need to change a thing. There is great mentoring, a stirring love, more than one great test of the hero s character, and a gift to be given to future generations of Tim s family. For this reason I award Tim 5 Heroes out of 5. Movie: Heroes:

GREG: I agree with you Scott. Like other movies by the same writer, About Time is a touching love story with a message we can all take home. I had the luck to see it twice and it got better the second time around. I give About Time 4 out of 5 Reels and 5 out of 5 Heroes for Tim. Movie: Heroes:

It's a film in two halves. What starts as a rom-com with a gimmick quickly becomes a refreshing examination of life and time itself. About Time doesn't waste our own time explaining the hows and whys of its time travel mechanic. That's not important here. Through Domhnall Gleeson we explore the the depths of romantic love, but also the love of family and friends which is of high importantance. Yes, the film is sentimental, maybe overly so. It might as well be the equivilant of a "Live, Love, Laugh" poster. But really, sometimes we all need a shot of that saccharine bullshit into our veins every now and then.
The greatest movie of all time.  It's a rom-com that goes so much deeper.  It's about life, how it happens to you and how to live it.  So soft, so gentle and despite its sci-fi mechanisms, so real.
A different kind of love story. Imaginative, original and adorable.

"About Time" stars Domhnall Gleeson as Tim, a socially awkward young adult who finds out he can travel in time (inside his own timeline) and decides to use his powers to find love. The target of his pursuits is the also somewhat awkward Mary (Rachel McAdams). There are definitely some questions regarding the specific mechanics of time travel, however, it is not a big issue, since this is a romantic comedy with elements of time travel and not a sci-fi film about time travel. The key plot element seems to be the sort of self-induced "Groundhog Day" with Tim's repeated attempts to make Mary fall in love with him. Surprisingly, time travel does not actually happen that often. In the second half of the film it is only used two or three times.

This is a romantic comedy, meaning it has to tick two very important boxes: romance and comedy. There is definitely chemistry between the leads. Tim and Mary are very similar: they are both a bit socially awkward, shy, but also very witty. The dialogue between them highlights their similarities and feels very real. Romance: check. The dialogue is overall fantastic, laced with British dry wit. Contributing greatly to the comedy are the supporting characters surrounding Tim and Mary, like Tim's quirky free-spirited sister or his bitter playwright landlord. The scenes between Tim and his father (Bill Nighy) are some of the best in the film. Every character is unique and quirky almost to a fault. Comedy: check.

However, the movie fails in plot and plot structure, which is rather unfortunate, considering the interesting concept. A tried and true format for films is to have a tense conflict that the protagonist tries to solve throughout the film despite the many obstacles thrown in his way. This keeps the audience invested in every scene. This film does not do that, but rather it is an episodic series of minor conflicts. The pattern is: a scene or two introducing the conflict, then a scene resolving the conflict, and then a scene or two of Tim and Mary just being in love. And repeat. The conflicts rarely revolve around their relationship. Be it good or not, but here we do not have the formulaic romantic comedy structure and on paper this format actually makes sense in keeping with the themes of the film - living life and appreciating its ups and downs. But this does not translate onto the screen very well. The lack of central tension results in boredom. Also, it means there isn't much of depth to the character of Tim. Therefore, when the movie ends, it just sort of happens.

Speaking of the ending, the similarities between this film and Richard Curtis' previous success "Love Actually" (2003) are very noticeable. Firstly, the ending of "About Time" is stylistically identical to the opening of "Love Actually", complete with a disembodied voice talking about life and love over shots of random residences of London. The plot's misgivings can also be traced back to the 2003 film. "Love Actually" is an ensemble comedy with each character having their own conflict and resolution. The lack of one central conflict works in that film, because there is also no central protagonist. "About Time", on the other hand, is a single protagonist film with a multi-protagonist structure.

Overall, the film is enjoyable despite its shortcomings. There are plenty of embarrassing and hilarious situations that Tim finds himself in. As for those looking for romance - Tim and Mary's relationship is exactly what you want. But with a better structure to the plot and better use of the under-utilized time travel aspect, the film could have been so much more.
Love the music, love the plots, and like the actors

WHAT I LIKED: As a general rule, I think Richard Curtis is hugely under-appreciated as a film-maker, and nowhere is that more the case than where his 'About Time' is concerned. Now of course his overall reception is largely down to genre-prejudice, but for me this film is the best example of how he always balances everything so well, and in doing so creates a genuinely excellent movie that still largely gets critically forgotten.
For a start, About Time strikes the perfect balance between taking itself seriously, and having a bit of fun, and that exists both in the story itself, as well as in the tone of the film where different types of humour are used at all the right times to relieve from all the emotion. It is a silly plot after all, but it's yet again one that you can take a bit seriously because its characterisation and relationships are so well-built by Curtis and his amazing cast. The investment you have is nurtured too, as there's just the right levels of both soppy happy endings and difficult twists and turns to keep you there without swallowing you up or spitting you out. It's also paced rather elequently (which agreeably is something that can't be said for all of Curtis' ventures) and has some lovely themes that are yet again treated with the right level of exploritative seriousness and light-hearted whit too. Basically, About Time works because it's a proper balance between excellent 'rom' and brilliant 'com,' but putting those words together sadly puts some off before they even try it.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: Maybe the silly (and often over-convenient) plot lose some sense of the relateable realities of love, life, and death, but if you take it as not-so-seriously as the movie does, you wont really mind at all.
VERDICT: It's About Time people gave Richard Curtis a big pat on the back. He delivers his most balanced film here, and I really love it.

This movie has a special place in my heart. One of my dearest friends recommended it, so I watched it one day, and by next day I had to rewatch it because I loved it so much!

 So, a brief synopsis (no spoilers! promise): The story is about Tim, a regular guy without luck in the love department. On his 21st birthday he finds out that all the men in his family have the ability to travel in time. But as Uncle Ben taught us: "with a great power comes a great responsibility", so he must use this for something good and can make his life better. Can you guess on what he's going to use it? YES! You guessed right! On getting a girlfriend. So this is only the beginning but soon Tim will find out about the complications of time travel and problems of everyday life.

 Now that you have the premise and have seen the scores and stuff, let me tell you what I think.
Far from being pure science fiction or just another corny movie, it meets in between with a good balance of reality and fantasy. It makes us hope that we can live the way Tim does. It's the kind of movie you can enjoy every single time you watch it, not because it's the best movie ever! But because it explores our humanity through the humanity of the characters. Rather than make them strong or undefeatable, Curtis achieves what every filmmaker must: to show the vulnerability of a human being, with well rounded characters and not stereotyped. 

 You see, About Time speaks to you about some things that we already know, stuff in the back of our minds, but it manages to bring it all together and remind us of the importance of enjoying life, and living it to the fullest. My dad would say that is a men's movie (like he said about The Secret Life of Walter Mitty) but I disagree (on both). Because it is not about just a man, it's more of the daily challenges and the big decisions that we have to make where we can all relate to that, not only men or only women, but every human being in touch with their emotions. An for me that's what makes it a great movie. 

 To tell you the truth I have absolutely no idea how many times I've seen it! I just lost count of them after the first two. I almost made a party when Netflix uploaded it a few months ago! So that's me, I watch movies so many times I learn the dialogues (you can expect that of a child I know, but not at 25 years old)

Is there anything more pleasant than a film that just makes you feel all warm inside? About Time, the latest from romantic comedy writer/director Richard Curtis, is one of those films. It's a delightful little experience that just oozes sentimentality and warmth, even when it delves into more serious subjects. The heart and soul of this film ultimately stems from the lead performance, that of Domhnall Gleeson. Gleeson nails every facet of this character that the story requires: his naive charm is irresistable, his aimlessness is relatable, and his comedic timing is on point. The comparisons between Gleeson and Hugh Grant are completely on-point. Alongside him, Rachel McAdams' own natural sense of charm is a perfect match for Gleeson, and the two work impeccably work together. Also worth mentioning is Bill Nighy, who is utterly perfect as the father figure to Gleeson's Tim. The sort of sci-fi aspect it brings to the table, the Tim's ability to travel back in time as he chooses, is more of an extension of the themes on hand than a gimmick, which is a refreshing change of pace that never detracts from the main romance. If there's anything to nitpick, its the blatant breaking of the time travel rules (established very early on in the film) in the break-into-three portion of the film, but its a plot hole that's so easily forgiven because of the pure joy this film is sure to instill.

A recent book (Twee: The Gentle Revolution in Music, Books, Television, Fashion, and Film by Mark Strand) has announced the arrival of The Age of Twee. Twee, if I understand it, is a generational cultural movement like punk, but is more or less the opposite of punk, and to some extent a reaction against it. Where punk was cynical, gritty, defiant, aggressive, and disorderly, twee is sentimental, gentle, retiring, friendly, and innocent. If punk is a cold slice of leftover pepperoni pizza, twee is a fresh baked ginger cupcake with vanilla frosting.

About Time seems an exemplar of The New Twee consciousness. This film set in contemporary Britain (Cornwall and London)is the story of Tim, the son of an eccentric family whose men have always had the ability to travel back through time, as his father (Bill Nighy) informs him on his 21st birthday. Understandably skeptical at first, Tim finds he actually can time travel, a talent he devotes mostly to trying, rather awkwardly, to manage his relationships with women, finally finding his true love in the form of an attractive though somewhat nerdy American girl, Mary (Rachel McAdams.)

The story is what might be called a "soft" time travel film: the time travel is effected simply by willing it, with no technology involved, and works only going into the past and back to the present starting point, so there are no science-fiction-like visions of the future. The movie emphasizes relationships over physics, and though it's frankly sentimental, and I thought a little long for the material, the script is intelligent and the acting very good.

I think About Time would appeal to those who want to see a film that interestingly combines romantic comedy and time travel fantasy, and who don't mind if it's a little, or more than a little, "twee." It may really be a three star film overall, but I'll add a fourth star for the film's exploration of some of the personal ethical implications of time travel, an issue which seems rarely considered in other time travel films I've seen. Advisory: ridiculously rated R for occasional language and a few explicit but fairly mild sex scenes. The Universal Blu-Ray disc is of very good quality; there is also a standard DVD available.

A charming and sentimental love story.  What it lacks in sophistication with its element of time travel, it makes up for in likeable characters, subtle humour and gentle thematic messaging.  Its divergence from the expected romantic-comedy formula is initially a little strange and potentially off-putting, but ultimately turns out to be a refreshing change.  You'll need a box of Kleenex for this one.
Unabashedly sweet and romantic, About Time may not be original and suffers from Richard Curtis' unfocused direction, but it is a well-acted and charming look on love and family.

The first hour of this film is terrible, clearly aimed towards an American audience with its impression that we're all upper-middle-class in Britain, land our first teenage flats in the affluent Abbey Road Beatle fame area of north-west London, and look a bit like Prince Harry if were young free and single.  The dialogue is also crass, but suitably so for the aforementioned... this is even before the ridiculous plot is revealed, or the inevitable arrival of an American on the scene (just to confirm this is not a film aimed at a British audience).  The second part however develops a meaningful father-son relationship through the crux of the plot, and it does get a lot better.

Appealing, funny, entertaining film. Young guys who have problems meeting women can relate to it. Also, the injection of time-travel as an enabler of fixing past mistakes is something lots of people would love to do - so again, something very relatable - and it is an interesting utilization of a primarily sci-fi idea into a drama/love story.       
A couple of points of criticism:
(1) More conservative depicted sexual mores would sell it better among conservatives, domestic and foreign - and not take anything away from its charm. Hopping into bed after the first date is a bit much.     
(2) It was said in the movie that you can only go backward in time - not forward. However, the time-travelling actions of Tim, the lead character, goes back in time, then forward to his travel-back point. thus, the principle of not going forward is not followed. 

Actually, even going back does not work. the only thing that Tim could have done is appear as his own twin brother to coach his former self to make corrections to errors that he knows he is going to make.  

So basically, logic - and, I might add, the current string theory science - tells us that going back in time to ones own original consciousness is impossible. No matter. It makes for an interesting film.

This is a lovely movie that has all the hallmarks of a Richard Curtis movie; it's funny and touching and ultimately quite joyous in its observations of life. It's a strange mix of fantasy, sci-fi and romance, yet it works. The story follows Tim (Domhnall Gleeson) who finds out from his father (Bill Nighy) on his 21st birthday that he can travel in time, something all men in his family are able to do. As he learns how to use his power he accidentally erase his chance meeting with love Mary (Rachel McAdams) so has to set about altering tis course, with some humourous results. Indeed, it is amusing to watch Tim move through events in his life with the realisation that he could go back and fix them if he said or did something wrong. But it is also quite heartbreaking as he uses it to further his relationship with his father.

There are some movies which retain the emotional engagement of the first viewing, no matter how many times you see it - and 'About Time' is one of them. What sets out as a sensitive, yet hilarious, romantic comedy quickly evolves into a much deeper, and stronger, portrayal of responsibility and human bond. Domhnall Gleeson shines in his role as the smart, loyal, corageous 'Tim', and it is his relationship with his father (Bill Nighy) which is the real gem. It is most certainly a love story, but a story of love between the family and the people who come into their lives. Absolutely wonderful, and refreshingly sincere. You will laugh out loud, and tears may well fall - but in the end you would not have it any other way.

Sometimes a flawed and somewhat predictable movie can be enjoyed by the watcher due to its charm and inoffensive manner, Richard Curtis's time traveling love story About Time is one of those films, a film that provides enough laughs and heartfelt moments that only Scrooge himself could not find enjoyment in this tale.

Brendan Gleeson's very own Domhnall Gleeson gets his first big leading role here as our lovable ginger time traveling lawyer Tim and he does a fine job at being a lovable red haired version of Hugh Grant. Gleeson's chemistry with season rom-com veteran Rachel McAdams is made believable also with her slightly underused talents coming to the fore in most of their scenes and the eventual on screen romance plays out in a believable manner despite all the time traveling business occurring throughout. While this love story is a major part of About Time, Curtis has also positioned the film to be more than a man meets girl tale with a twist, and with this choice has made a film all the better for it.

Playing Tim's Dad is veteran British actor Bill Nighy, who with Gleeson gives the film another side that usual rom-coms would be hard pressed to have. It's within this relationship between time traveling father and son that the movie finds many relatable and confronting issues to deal with and by films end the audience's emotional investment has been well and truly earned thanks to it. In concerns to Curtis as a director, it's also a departure for the man who has not shown this side of himself as a director before but that's not to say the film lacks a few well-earned laughs and Curtis usual array of colorful supporting characters, which is evidenced in Tom Hollander's playwright Harry.

Coming in at roughly 2 hours About Time covers a lot of ground and in doing so it would be fair to say that the films first half pales in comparison to its much more concise and impactful second half, but as a whole it all comes together in such a way that it's hard to fully criticize. Watched with the right mindset About Time is the perfect movie for a night in and stepping stone for lead Gleeson to find his feet in the world of big budget tent pole movies.

Some of the reviews are, IMO, unfair to this movie by dismissing it as a rom-com, but it's way more than that.  Rom-coms end after "boy gets girl" and we're to assume that they live happily ever after.  But in About Time, boy gets girl about half way through and we see life go on.  Their interactions as a married couple are gorgeous, and the stuff dealing with having kids is even better.  Its handling of the death of a parent is achingly spectacular, as is its depiction of life going on afterward.  While younger people might be confused that the movie didn't end at the wedding, to me that's where the movie becomes its most powerful.  If you are a grownup with a spouse and kids, who has dealt with the decline and/or death of your parents and this film doesn't move you, there just might be something missing inside you.

Bill NIghy as the dad is phenomenal, and Rachel McAdams - in a movie where she's only the third hottest woman - steals the show. This movie is just so Richard Curtis. It has posh people swearing liberally, kookie people saying delightfully unexpected things, people being utter jerks to each other in endearing ways, a token American, stiff upper lips from all and sundry, Bill Nighy...oh, but then there's a time-travel element, which is not very Richard Curtis at all. The means by which the time-travel happens is just silly, that's got to be said up front. There's no Back To The Future style attempt to explain the science and you get the feeling no-one has thought it through at all, and you also get the feeling that if you were to try to think it through now, on no possible level would it make sense. The ginger lead...well I just don't think he would actually stand a chance with Mary. And definitely not with Charlotte. I mean, what was that scene all about. But back to the time travel...the bit where he could go back and hang out with his dead dad...that worked. That was emotional. It was kind of slow all round though. Charlotte...wow...she really is a stunner. I just don't know what to make of this movie all round, other than to say it's just...so desperately Richard Curtis. That's good I think. Or not. I don't know.

"About Time" começa como toda boa comédia romântica, mas gradativamente vai se afastando do clichê e dos diálogos fáceis para se tornar uma obra diferente, carregada de inspiração e sentimentos. Richard Curtis sacrifica a ciência por trás das viagens no tempo em nome da simplicidade (e do público) do filme e dinamiza a história, rápida e recheada de takes e twists.

O elenco entrega uma atuação tocante e contida; todos estão bem, com destaque para o trio principal: Domhnall Gleeson, Rachel McAdams e Bill Nighy. A fotografia, a direção de arte, a palheta de cores, o ambiente de cada take, tudo é minuncioso, belo. Os diálogos são hilários, os momentos tensos, de fato são tensos, e, ao final dos 120 minutos de longa, você se pergunta porque o filme "já acabou" e parte para a reflexão. Realmente uma produção que merece deleite.

if I could time travel I'd go back a few hours and pick a different movie to watch. As a "time travel" type movie About Time fails by not committing to being a movie about time travel and instead treats it like a weird solution to fix life's trivial errors. It's only at the end where it's actually used for something that makes sense by using time travel to spend time with a loved one before they passed away.  The big picture it tries to convey is sweet but overall the story is messy and made up of small plot points that are meant to be important but aren't developed enough to move past so they don't quite fit together. There is absolutely nothing that surprised me or was profound enough to be memorable and I wish I followed through with my urge to turn it off when it got to the hour and a half mark. About Time

A rare example of a romantic comedy done in a fresh, memorable, and heartfelt way, About Time is an immensely enjoyable film. It takes an outlandish premise, that of time travel, and puts it in a narrative context that makes one hardly question it, and actually adds something to the story. Far from being a gimmick, it makes for a genuinely interesting exploration of the meaning of love, free will, death, and the choices we make. The chemistry between Domhnall Gleeson and Rachel McAdams is outstanding, as the two enliven every scene. It's a captivating film, it's an emotional film, and it's a funny film.

This film was most definitely my favorite of all the films I watched in 2014. I liked it so much that I gifted it to my best friend for Christmas. I even bought myself a copy, and I so rarely buy DVDs that are not intended for my children these days. 

The movie is essentially about a young man who inherits his father's ability to time travel on his 21st birthday. You can imagine that this could lead to a very silly and fanciful film, when in fact, About Time remains completely sincere and unexpectedly moving. 

  Lead character, Tim, has many lessons to learn - some about the use of time travel, and some about life in general. His aim is to use his newfound power as a means to romance. When Tim meets Mary, his plan becomes less of a desire and more of a need. This is a very unique coming of age tale; clever and warmingly sentimental. Bill Nighy as the father is absolute perfection. I never expected to need a box of tissues for this movie, but it certainly is packed full of surprises. 

  We truly need more films like this.

About Time proves that a film about time travel must not necessarily be a science fiction or fantasy, but that it can also be a potent drama or precisely a family drama. About time has a lot of good moments but the scenes that connect these moments may tend to hack off the pace of the movie. All the acting involved is great with Bill Nighy deserving a special mention.

The theatrical poster for "About Time" suggests that it is a rip-off of "The Time Traveler's Wife" - they even brought in Rachel McAdams!  But this film is anything but a cheesy chick flick; instead, "About Time" is a thought-provoking story about life and how we can learn to better appreciate each day.  Director Richard Curtis is well-known for his romantic comedies such as "Notting Hill" and the Bridget Jones movies, but this script digs a lot deeper than most.  Curtis tapped into the creative complexity that he used to write "Love Actually" and the result is this clever, heartwarming, and frustrating story about a man learning the personal consequences of changing the past.  The film was criticized for its plot holes, but this film can't be approached like "Primer" and other sci-fi nerd  films (I mean that in a good way) that use science to prove the possibility of time travel.  The story is about living, not travelling through time.  It does have its cutesy moments, but I would still recommend this to the manliest people that I know.  Concepts like living each day twice to enjoy the little moments and using time travel to extend your time on earth are fascinating, while the characters live out a complex love story.  All of the acting is great, particularly Bill Nighy and Domhnall Gleeson.  I watched "About Time" to make my wife happy  but, in the end, I was the one who fell in love with this story.

Overrated, sappy, safe-territory crowd-pleaser. Do something useful with the time and money put into this overdone distraction. It is a perfect 5/10 film. Half of it works, it's funny, it's even quite sweet. Half of it is utterly useless, overly sentimental, and a waste of time. I am beginning to really hate the tendency to burst into tears and sing a film's praises when watching some made up people live made up lives and do things we wish we could do. That's not what film is to me; it is more than just insipid wishful thinking, it has to be creative, clever, entertaining at least! This just lost steam and piled on the easy tearjerker moments until one of the most nauseating final monologues I have heard in years. Domhnall Gleeson, you're great, and I know you needed the money and the screen time, but please, pick less BS films from now on. You'll earn a lot more respect.

I wasn't really sure about this movie because it's labeled as a romantic comedy, so naturally I was skeptical. But it turns out it's not really a romantic comedy at all, it's a drama with a weird sci-fi plot element. The movie is about a guy who discovers that the ability to travel back in time runs in his family, and how he experiments with this ability with sometimes positive, sometimes negative results. So yeah, it's totally silly, so make sure to leave your rational brain at the door. And wait a second... didn't Rachel McAdams already play a time-travelers wife??? She clearly has a type! Anyway, the movie does have romantic themes, but that's only one of many as it is a surprisingly complex film. It starts with a rom-commy feel to it, but it soon changes and you discover that the real relationship that this film explores is that between the father and son. It's also quite emotional and really tugs your heartstrings, which I did not expect. Domhnall Gleeson is great as the lead, he carries the story entirely on his own and sells both the character and all the relationships in the movie. I do think that the movie is not as cohesive as it could have been (the tone drastically changes about mid-way through) and it's about 20 minutes too long and starts to drag in the second half. You'd think a movie called "About Time" would be more cautious about its pacing and total runtime. Even so, it's worth watching, the story is original and executed well and the performances are solid... even Rachel McAdams' stupid face was only mildly annoying. Though the premise is obviously ridiculous and (like all time-travel movies) riddled with plot-holes, the movie has so much heart that the logistical flaws in the story don't matter at all. And the overall message is poignant and one we all need to be reminded of every now and again.

About Time is a good movie. It does a lot of things right - there is a very unique and riveting screenplay here with some outstanding scenes, the actors and actresses seem very invested in their characters, and the movie is rarely ever boring. However, I cannot say this is a great movie because I wish it were more focused. There are two quintessential relationships going on in this film - the relationship between Tim and Mary, and the relationship between Tim and his father. The movie takes most of its time to focus on Tim and Mary - as it should; their budding relationship is an extremely important part of the entire movie and Tim's life. Yet in the end, it is Tim's father that we must say goodbye to, someone who - in my opinion - is not in the spotlight enough in the movie. I enjoyed watching Tim spend his final moments with his father, yet I felt that the ending could have been so much more. I also felt that the comedy side of the movie fell incredibly short - besides a couple of remarkably funny scenes, I very rarely laughed. It didn't take away from the movie, but when it's referred to as a comedy, I expect a little more effort. But regardless of my complaints, About Time is still worth a shot. It's reassuring to see that Domhnall Gleeson is able to carry himself well in a lead role, as I'm sure he'll be a big name actor when Star Wars, Episode VII is released.

This film has generally been advertised as if it were a romantic comedy with a sci-fi twist; and while that much is certainly true of the first half of the film, and that part works well enough, in the second half it actually evolves into something even better and more interesting. I was actually caught off-guard by just how emotionally affecting this movie would be; by the end, I was genuinely touched, moved even, in a way I'm almost never moved by anything anymore. The performances are great, especially Bill Nighy as the protagonist's father. Writer-director Richard Curtis has made his share of minor classic romantic comedies, but I think this might actually be the best of all his films. I highly recommend it.

A Richard Curtis rom com, complete with socially awkward middle class Englishman in love with an American, only it isn't Hugh Grant playing the former role this time. Review In A Nutshell:

About Time tells the story of Tim, who has been told by his father at the age of 21 that the men in his family has the ability to travel back in time.

I didn't want to give more away of the film's story as I personally feel that this film isn't about what happens to Tim, but rather what he feels and the ideas that director, Richard Curtis, is trying to relay to its audience. The film is certainly sentimental but I personally felt it was appropriate for this kind of tale and his previous film Love Actually proved to me that he has the ability to tackle heavy sentiment. The film is marketed as a romance film, and for the first half, that certainly is the case, but the latter half changes its focus towards more serious and mature, which parallels with Tim's growth in life. Curtis delivers his trademark humour that doesn't affect the established atmosphere; it is present only to create a sense of accessibility and also to give the audiences a rest between weighty moments. The film resolves itself in such a way, that I feel is quite strikingly similar to what the director did for his debut film Love Actually, where the human story slowly converges to a universal message. I didn't mind so much that the director repeats himself as I was engaged with everything that the film had to offer, creating weight and significance regardless of how the end would turn out.

The film's hand held photography was handled quite well, capturing moments like as if they were memories, making it easier to empathise with our protagonist. The film's score was also highly impressive, with my only complaint being slightly repetitive. There is this layer of tenderness and warmth to be found in the music, which certainly amplified the film's emotions.

The film featured a great performance from Domhnall Gleeson, playing our protagonist Tim. Gleeson was able to let his role feel empathetic and genuine. He didn't let the character be defined by one or two key attributes but rather he projects a naturalistic structure, which helped with the accessibility. Rachel McAdams as the film's romantic interest was charming and cute but couldn't match Gleeson's performance, as also he is given a much larger focus and screen time in the film. Bill Nighy, who was one of the best aspects of Curtis' Love Actually, shows a completely different side in this film, as the sentimental but yet slightly funny father; proving once again that he has the potential to be a scene robber when given the chance.

About Time may not appeal to everyone due to its warm, cuddly atmosphere and plot holes but it certainly delivers a strong message that is applicable towards each every person that is living and has ever lived.

The first time I saw the trailer for this film, I knew I would like it, but often times the trailer surpasses the actual film. Fortunately, this was not one of those films. Initially, this just seemed like the usual rom-com with a bit of the time traveling twist but it turns out to be much, much more. I have definitely fallen in-love with Richard Curtis' style of directing. "Love Actually" is and has remained one of my most favorite films of all time and I think this film is my 2nd "Love Actually"; I have never fallen in-love with a film so fast and so hard. I am completely sold. First, the was definitely a heart-tugging-tear-jerker-laugh-out-loud roller coaster ride. Every single person in this film was brilliant-- not a boring character in the lot. I initially wanted to see this because of Bill Nighy because he is just so bloody brilliant-- I love him! Domhall Gleeson was awesome, he was just too adorably awkward enough and dory-cute that the role seemed tailor made for him and Rachel McAdams, who is getting typecast in these roles, had beautiful on-screen chemistry with Gleeson that it would be difficult to imagine anyone else in the role. She was just too charming. It always a pleasant surprise to watch favorite familiar faces pop up in films: Tom Hollander whom I adore from the Kiera Knightley "Pride & Prejudice" film and from "Pirates of the Caribbean" and Margot Robbie (who played Laura Cameron from the t.v. series "Pan Am"). Also, I award extra brownie points whenever a film has actors who've appeared in Harry Potter: Domhnall Gleeson (as Bill Weasley), Bill Nighy (as Minister Rufus Scrimgeour) and of course, Richard Griffiths (Uncle Vernon). 
The brilliant thing about "Love Actually is how well all the intertwining subplots weave together to make one coherent film, this film did that beautifully as well-- not a single insignificant plot in the entire film-- it was absolute perfection!!! I cannot gush enough about this film, my heart still aches at how poignant this film is and how wonderfully touching the message was. It's just absolutely, positively one of the best films I've seen in a long while. I absolutely love(d) it.
Puts you in the best mood you will ever want!!

About Time seems your run of the mill love story with a quirky twist from the outset. Its message is heavy handed but sweet. It's missing something I can't quite put my finger on but with witty writing and charming performances, it's easy to look past any flaws.

This is a film for the flawed romantic, who really does want to watch happily ever after happen without all the dramatic loss and heartbreak. "About Time" is not a film that delays pain, or revels in mind bending configurations dealing with time travel. For the subset that enjoyed "The Time Traveler's Wife" but wished it was a funny, woebegone tale of guy gets girl, guy makes girl happy for the rest of their lives, this is the film for you. It's honest, it's emotional, and it aims to show the pleasant irreverence of life in all aspects. It's especially tender when dealing with drug abuse, relationship problems, and death's presence. Still, it stays whimsical throughout, a feat that other fluffy romantic films can only dream about attaining.

A wonderful ode to live and all its pitfalls and little pockets of loveliness that make it so amazing to be part of it. Yes, it is a romantic comedy but it never deliberately strains the level of tragedy to a level that would make a Shakespearen tragedy burst out of its book covers, but keeps a tender, distanced and first and foremost relatable pace. The characters are all believable, especially Gleeson, McAdams, Nighy, all of which deliver stunning performances that are the more believable for their understatment of emotions, a welcome change to the exagerrated fare offered by Hollywood, which - just like adding artificial flavours to strawberries - lets us forget the true taste of life. Yes, the time travel bits are a tad weird, dont really fit the whole tone of the movie and I dare say they dont adhere to most of the common "rules" (arbitrary as the may be) of time travel. Yet, I look at the whole aspect of time travel within this movie as a stylised form of narrative insight, into one's life, motivation and thoughts on the past and what we would change if we could. All in all, the future is just  the past of tomorrow.
Great script. Makes you just want to enjoy life to the max with others!
my absolute favorite movie of all time.

I admit to avoiding this film as I believed its preview made it look like some overly sugared and cloying treacle made even more unbearably sweet by being drenched in a thick syrup of fake romanticism.  I feared this because of its 'Groundhog Day' plot device that would have allowed About Time to easily over-do it in the dreamily amorous sigh/swoon department as it is the story of a young man who discovers he has the ability to travel in time to change small events in his life for either better or worse.  The romantic angle of the film was heavily played-up/hyped in the trailers as the young man, Tim (Domhnall Gleeson - True Grit), decides to use his ability to get himself a girlfriend and a nearly perfect relationship with Mary (Rachel McAdams - The Notebook).  While romance is a major portion of the movie (and its primary selling point), the film's story between father (Bill Nighy - Love, Actually) and son is just as important -- and the one I actually found to be more touching.  About Time is a relationship drama with a rather flimsy sci-fi twist (as most of the time travel "rules" seem to be made up as the film progresses).  I can definitely see why About Time was touted as a "date film" but had the father-son story been used in the advertising some more I would think there would have been less aversion to it for some.  As one who doesn't mind romance -- the director's first film, Love Actually, is an excellent film that is almost ALL romance -- this one did strike me as too much so in the beginning; but it really wasn't at all.  Curtis has weighted it well and it comes across as something rather wise ... and one I am glad I ended up watching.
Interesting take on time travel and how it can be used to better family life.

There are some major logical fallacies in this movie in terms of the time traveling it. Nevertheless, it was sentimentally entertaining which gave me some good laughs and almost pushed out some tears. To describe the movie in a couple words: inoffensively delightful.

Now I remember the poster.  I was thinking it must be a tacky love story when looked at the poster last year until I finally watched the movie today. I would say the way it tells the story is refreshing and much like "500 days with Summer". Love the music and need to find out all the songs! About the story, when I just see "time traveling", good, that's another sci-fi. Then it proves me totally wrong. It's more of family and love thing. The happiness formula about appreciating every moment you have right now when the dad got cancer, and how the guy uses time traveling to visit  the passed away dad is just so touching at the moment. Bill Nighy is just great as always!
A movie about a guy who learns he can time travel just by thinking about it... then doesn't ever bother to do it.  Possibly the all-time worst use of an otherwise cool plot device.

A heartfelt movie that you cannot truly appreciate until you've loved & lost; until you've lived enough to have experienced euphoria & devastation; until you're far enough into your life to distinguish between living & having lived.
"We're all traveling through time together, every day of our lives. All we can do is do our best to relish this remarkable ride."
This one got me because it's me
This is just a great little movie. Not a sappy love story, but it is about love and life. You won't regret the time spent seeing it.
Absolutely loved it. Was bawling like a baby - same as when I watch the Notebook. Beautiful story with sad moments but overall positive message with lots of love and laughter built in throughout.

It turns out that the movie is not about a love story. It's more about fatherhood. It's a shame it had to sell the love story part in its promotion to get people watching this movie.

The directing and the cinematography is absolutely beautiful. In terms of directing, this is a wonderful swan song for Richard Curtis' directing career.

However, the story lacked strong conflict. The love story in this movie did not have any conflict at all. It seemed like it's too much of a perfect romantic story, which felt unrealistic.

And the plot holes in this story is very noticeable. To get my point, I had to list down the time traveling rules, applied in the movie.

1-)Only male members of the family can travel in time.: This rule was broken when Tim traveled way back in time from the beginning of the movie with his sister, Kit Kat. The question why Kit Kat was allowed to time travel as long as she is with her brother is not answered.
2-)Only travel to the past is possible: This rule was broken when Tim arrives in the past and then goes back to the present time. The question why Tim cannot go to the future, but can go back to the present is not answered.
3-)It is impossible to go back in time before you were born: The first rule that wasn't broken.
4-)Traveling back to a time before your child is born will cause a different child to be born and the original child will be lost: And the last rule that wasn't broken either.

With these plot holes and the story lacking conflict makes the movie a bit boring to watch.

The humor, however, saved the movie. It was funny and smartly written.

While this time traveling romantic-comedy movie is not memorable, its humor, charm and beautiful setting will remain you to watch the movie until the credits roll.

this film makes you think about how precious your time is with the people you love. life goes by so fast and its movies like this that inspire you to treasure every second. i cried my eyes out on the 1st viewing and it had the same effect second time round. i absolutely loved this film and if you truley love anyone i think you will too.

I came into this movie expecting very little, but instead got nothing. The first of many problems that came to my attention was the pacing. The movie gives you no sense of time passing. The whole experience was dreary. The next problem was the humour, or lack there of. This film was simply not funny. One of the worst scenes was when the heroine was trying on different dresses that she would were to some event I don't care about. The scene went too long, wasn't funny, and contributed nothing. I was offended that this was placed under the comedy section of the video store I rented it from. Apparently they closed down the shlock section. The next problem was the broken concept the movie tried to pass as time travel. It seemed as though a toddler wrote the script and decided to make up the rules as he went along (not to insult toddlers). The next problem I noticed at about the half hour mark. The movie was too long. 45 minutes into the movie I attempted to concuss myself with the DVD case in a failed attempt to make the movie more enjoyable. All further attempts were fruitless. The next problem is that the characters had no development. Apparently the writer thought that making a character dress a certain way was all the development that was required. Another glaring issue was the cinematography. It was poor, but at least it wasn't terrible. The movie's (and I use this term lightly)  "message"  is so terribly contrived that it felt impure and horrid. The movie was ornately terrible and is all part of Richard Curtis' grand scheme of riding the contrived sentimental moment cash cow to the bank. What garbage! This may be one of the (if not the) worst movies I've ever seen.

If you like a love story and a bit of exiting fiction, then you may surely like 2013's Romantic Drama, 'About Time', you are an ordinary teenage guy, and you posses some common age instinct to have a girl friend, and you have missed lots of situations in your life of having a good girl friend, during this time you come to know that you have an ability to travel back to time and set the things back into the track, cool, isn't it? Well, then you began to use your super extraordinary power to set every situation perfect, you will have successful love story, better relation, no bad times etc, the concept is totally like you are controlling or better to say your correcting or directing your fate as you need, the only caution is to be wise in using that power, the overall story line is unique and catchy, the lead pairs Gleeson and Rachel are very fine with their on screen appearance and performance, the importance given to the character like Kit Kat and Harry by Tim shows the importance of relations, story had been neatly portrayed, the humor used in the movie is very hilarious and surely makes you laugh, sound track is fine, overall good gradable movie.

One of the most touching and well executed movies I have ever seen. I came in expecting another generic "guy chases girl" romantic comedy-drama with a twist of time traveling mixed in. Instead, this evolved into a film exploring the importance of family, choices, and happiness in one's life. Domhnall Gleeson was an unconventional but surprisingly relatable male lead who really did an excellent job in conveying his character's maturation and struggles, and his chemistry onscreen with Rachel McAdams seemed very genuine and not overly done. The scenes with Bill Nighy (who plays the father) and Gleeson were some of the most powerful and insightful scenes in the entire movie. I really believe this is one of Bill Curtis's best work and one of the best movies of 2013, and I actually enjoyed the third act of this movie more than "Her". While the movies overarching themes weren't as original or creative as "Her", the execution and focus of every scene in the last third of the film was almost perfect. The only downfall of this movie was its more awkward, generic plot development and ill-defined characters in the opening third of the movie, but this drawback really takes a backseat to how great the rest of the movie is. About Time may well be the two most purely pleasurable hours I've spent in the cinema all year
