Written and directed by Richard Curtis, who suffered a massive flop with the 1960's jukebox romp The Boat That Rocked (2009), returns to safe territory with his latest film. Although while it is a romantic comedy, it's one with a bit of sci-fi thrown into the mix, but it's one of a few films which manages to do sci-fi without using any CGI, and that makes this a bit of a rare beast. Tim Lake (Domhnall Gleeson) has just turned 21, and he's been told by his dad (Bill Nighy) that the men in his family have the ability to travel through time. Something Tim can't believe, until he tries it and he discovers what he can do. He moves from the family home in Cornwall to London. When he meets American Mary (Rachel McAdams), Tim believes he's found the love of his life, and he's not going to let her go, but life gets in the way, but he's able to use his time travelling abilities to put it right, but it doesn't always go to plan, and he ends up altering the course of his life, something Tim has to end up fixing again and again. It's a very British sort of time travel film, but it's a very personal film for Curtis, a romantic at heart, and a man with an impeccable taste in music as well. Gleeson puts in a brilliant performance, while McAdams has become a natural at doing time travel films after The Time Traveler's Wife (2009) and Midnight in Paris (2011).
The sentimental brilliance of how this movie is shot and acted outweighs the many holes in its uplifting plot. This one really yanks on the heart strings.

About Time elevates above the typical rom com because of the time travel element. However, the source of its cleverness is also its greatest flaw.

The movie never explains how or why the men in Tim's family can travel through time. While this may give the movie a magical quality, it comes in conflict with the film's tone, which is grounded in reality, save for the time travel. Even something as simple as saying that the family are descendants of Merlin or something would ease my query.

Despite that one plot hole, About Time is delightful. It is clever, well written, well shot and well acted. I enjoyed its sincerity most of all. The film's themes of family and love are played out to great effect. It's about cherishing all the moments in life, no matter how small they seem.

so sweat and delicate.

Before I watched this movie I thought it was going to be a boring generic romantic movie. And it has Rachel McAdams in it, not to offend her or anything I think she's a good artist, her romantic movie aren't good. The Notebook is boring as hell; I hated The Time Travelers Wife. But what drew me towards seeing this movie, was all of the positive reviews. It has a 69% on Rotten Tomatoes, it may not seem like much but it's fresh. I did not catch this movie in theaters. I waited until it was on Redbox. After seeing it I felt like I should have gone to theater so the people who made this movie got my money. I loved this movie. And I know what you are thinking, I am also shocked that I said that myself. Now let's start with the performances. Everyone is great. I think with a romantic movie, which is character driven, should have well written character and great performances from the cast. I think this movie achieved that. With Rachel McAdams character, Mary, the mixture of the writing and acting make this one of the most likable female leads in a romantic comedy. In Midnight in Paris Rachel McAdams plays this mean, unlikable person. But here it's a total 180. Her character is so likable; this is the type of person that you want to fall in love with. Domhnall Gleeson also does a very good job here. He is also likable and more relate able characters in a romantic movie. I may be sounding, or writing, like a broken record but this movie made all the characters likable, what can I say? Bill Nighy was great as the father. I just had to mention that. The chemistry between Rachel McAdams and Domhnall Gleeson is fantastic. They don't act like they are madly in love with one another. They don't hate each other all the time. Definitely one of the most realistic couples I have seen on screen. The premise is really cool. They get really creative using the whole time travel mechanism. Are there time paradoxes? Of course there are, every time travel movie I have seen so far has them. The movie is a feel good movie. But it works for the tone they are going for. It has some really funny moments. Sometime you get choked up. I had a great time watching this. Richard Curtis did a fantastic job making this movie. I will buy this on Blu-Ray as soon as I can. I am shocked that About Time is one of my favorite movies of 2013.
Beautiful, life-affirming, clever - and sadly overlooked at the multiplex.

I wasn't sure where it was going at first. The live-today-as-it's-your-last unfolded beautifully in the end. I left a half star off simply because I can't show it to my kids. The language and brief nudity wouldn't have been missed and maybe even pulled a pg-13. About Time, a rare exception that I didn't regret watching a rated R.

Is there sexual language and brief nudity that gives this an R rating? Yes. Is there an interesting sci-fi concept that doesn't reach its full potential? Yes. Is it about time (oh puns!) that you see this movie anyway? Still yes. If you missed "About Time" last year, as I did, you might want to give this one a watch. If you are able to push the sexual content aside, what you will find is a charming and endearing film about the consequences of decisions and appreciating the time that you do have in life. It's introduced early that the protagonist is able to travel back to specific moments in time to alter his history; critics have complained that this idea could have been greatly expanded upon but considering what the movie gives in terms of story, I think it's a minor quibble. Overall, "About Time" is a romantic journey that impresses a wide range of emotions throughout this heartwarming chick-flick.

Didn't really know what to expect from About Time but I really enjoyed it. It's a great story about life and love and the how the decisions you make, how you choose to live everyday weather to just get by or really live every moment as if it were your last. I even cried at the end.

Every now and then, a film comes along that changes the way I think about life. About Time is that kind of movie. This pleasantly unique film isn't just a love story, it's a life story. It showcases a variety of relationships that go beyond the traditional rom-com stereotypes. The story is uplifting, the acting is excellent and the humor is plentiful. This movie made me want to be a better person, and I'm very glad I saw it.

This isn't exactly in my repertoire of movies.  Chick flicks overwhelming lackluster, and the one that Richard Curtis (Love Actually) is known for is so far out there on the spectrum of strange - and not just because it's British - that I'd kind of forgotten about it.  However, with the lovely Rachel McAdams (Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows) and the incomparable Bill Nighy (The World's End) on board, I was willing to give this one a second look.  Domhnall Gleeson (Anna Karenina) makes for a somewhat compelling lead, and the story doesn't exactly play out like the previews suggest.  It's a much more family-centered dramedy, instead of the overtly romantic chick-flick that the previews make it out to be.  It's quaint, silly, and totally illogical, but I still kind of liked it.  The performances were pretty good, with Gleeson and Nighy really carrying the film, and leaving the bubbly McAdams, Lindsay Duncan (Alice in Wonderland), Lidya Wilson (Never Let Me Go), and the undervalued Tom Hollander (Hanna) to support them.  It's a lot better than I expected it to be, but it didn't blow me away.

Severely underrated this funny, sad, thoughtful film is a must-watch with the ultimate lesson of living each day with intense appreciation of  life itself. One to sit back, relax and not over-think as there are a few plot holes.  Lovely to see Margot Robbie whose English accent fits a lot more comfortably than her Brooklyn drawl in Wolf of Wall Street. Bill Nighy demonstrates that he can portray subtle deep emotion )n that stiff-upper lip way and  Domhnall Gleeson's foppish lead is miles apart from his Dublin  Irish background and portrayal of Bob Geldorf = very believable.  This movie played very strongly in Australia - much better than in the UK - probably because we are very comfortable with the egalitarian reverse aristocracy endemic here, whereas our English forefathers I think would have squirmed with the discomfort of seeing their class system lampooned in this way.  Rachel McAdams is very watchable as every boy's dream of the bespectacled girl next door type - cute and lovable. Lindsay Duncan is warmly snooty as the long-suffering mum and Lydia Wilson plays the hippy-out-of-time flibbertigibbet  that every family has one of.  Well rounded with the resident Alzheimer's uncle nicely underplayed by Richard Cordery.  All together a rich tapestry of real life with a comic-sad difference that appeals at multiple levels.  Satisfying for the soul.

I don't normally watch romcoms, but when I do there's a good chance it's a sappy British one that's bound to make me laugh and even try to get me to tear up. This is such an film. The story follows Tim (Domhnall Gleeson), a lanky insecure and hopeless romantic who is told by his father (the great Bill Nighy) that he and the men in his family have the ability to travel back in time to events they've already been to. Tim naturally exploits his new talent to make sure he won't botch up his chance to meet the girl of his dreams. And when he does, it takes some time travelling, awkward fumbles and fixing before he's going on a date with Mary (Rachel McAdams). The chemistry between the two leads is great as we follow them from the early days to their wedding and parenthood. The use of time travel though becomes more than a get out of jail for free card as the rules of time travel are made clear, such as you can't travel before the birth of a child. This gets complicated when death and sorrow is also a reality and Tim eventually learns that sometimes you can't change or fix everything and in the end you have to let life take it's course. The dialogue is witty and clever and despite the 2 hour run time never feels dragged on. There are a few scenes, such as the Kate Moss exhibition that feel a bit forced but they are ultimately overshadowed by the whole package. If you're a fan of director's Richard Curtis's work (Love Actually, Four Weddings and a Funeral, etc) then this one is up there with them.

"About Time" 10 Scale Rating: 7.5 (Very Good) ...

The Good: Very well done and well acted, "About Time" is touching, funny, and sentimental without being sappy. Domhnall Gleeson was excellent in a lead role and Bill Nighty was amazing (as usual) as his father. The characters are fleshed out and you easily grow attached to them. One of the more surprising films of 2013. 

The Bad: What prevents the film from being truly great is the inconsistencies found in the story. Early on you are given very clear cut rules for time travel, but more than halfway through the film those rules are inexplicably tossed aside. I can overlook something like that to an extent, but in this case it is so blatant and frequent that I just can't ... especially after they went to such lengths to make the rules clear to us.

About Time features time travel, a rather unconventional and at times ingenious usage too, but it's not about that, it's about love. There's the central love story between Domhnall Gleeson and Rachel McAdams, and then there's the father-son relationship between Gleeson and the great Bill Nighy. The thing I greatly appreciated is the point where most movies would end, at the "happy, rom-com ending," is only About Time's halfway point, and it uses the rest of the time to expand its themes and explore deeper down-to-earth, real life stuff further. The relationship between Nighy and Gleeson especially resonates, and that final exchange between them, oh man. Gleeson follows in his father's footsteps, making for another unlikely lead, but does an exceptional job of carrying things with his awkward energy and natural, easygoing charisma. Admittedly, some of the time travel intricacies are a little muddled, but by and large About Time is a successful navigation on the everyday things between life and death, and the love that ties them all together that makes it worthwhile.
Love, actually, is a worthy subject about which to make a movie. Even if this one is more about life itself, and living each day. Don't know that I've seen many movies I've liked more.

This film, unlike many time travel films out there, digs deep into the core of the insatiable, fundamental desire to become our 'better selves'. 'About Time' has successfully woven observations of the conceptions of mortality and daily emotional ordeals. What emerges is both a testament to the extraordinary potential that we can attain genuine fulfilment -- amid the tedium of our mundane affairs -- through our persistence in making better choices. 'About Time' is a rather compelling reminder that there exists no worthy replacement for a prudent and tenacious mind -- not even the 'astonishing' ability to traverse the space-time continuum unscathed.

From the director of 'Love Actually', who is also the writer of 'Four Weddings and a Funeral', 'Bean', 'Notting Hill' and the 'Bridget Jones' films, it sure raises some expectations for this particular fantasy romantic comedy drama film about time travel. 

Although it shares some similarities with 'The Time Traveler's Wife' (the same female lead actress, Rachel McAdams) and 'Groundhog Day', but rest assured, 'About Time' is a witty, intelligent, charming, sweet film with surprising depth and heart. The script was well written, the direction was great and the casts made a decent performance in their respective roles. 

The film done a fine job in balancing the comedic and dramatic elements of the story, providing enough laughter and allowing it to flow smoothly without feeling too overly long despite its 2 hours running time.

Despite the time-traveling plot device, the story focuses on the father-son relationship of Tim and his dad and the lovely romantic relationship between Tim and Mary, without being too sappy, too overly lovey-dovey or too sentimental. The message or overall theme of the film about appreciating life as if it was your last was subtle and not too forceful or preachy.The selection of songs for the film was appropriate and not too overly done for the emotional scenes.The on-screen chemistry between Rachel and Domhnall are convincing enough for the audience to watch them going through life together. On the other hand, Domhnall and Bill, as father and son, their connection is felt throughout the film and certainly evoke some poignant memories when watching them together.

It's one of the best romantic comedies this year had to offer, better than the disappointing 'Time Traveler's Wife'. It's a great date movie that's not to be missed.

Time travel is by far my favorite theme for films, books, TV shows, and basically every form of entertainment. I love to see the different methods that are used for time travel, the way people use the power, and the way changing history alters their reality. When I saw this film advertised as a romantic comedy with a time travel element added in I was sold. What I got was so much more than just a romantic comedy. One of the best things this movie does is get straight to the point. From the preview trailer we already know the setup, and luckily the reveal of Tim's power is about 5 minutes into the film. I always hate when we know the premise of the film, but it takes almost half the film to get there. Fitting the premise of the movie, About Time doesn't waste our time setting up the story, it just jumps right into telling it. So we have young Tim who is part of a family where the men have the ability to travel through time (as long as it is within their own lifetime.) It's an interesting idea because Tim's father tells Tim that using his power to get big things like riches or fame isn't worth it. Instead it's more important to concentrate on making your life happier. The problem is the one thing he truly wants in life is love, and it seems even time travel can't create that for him.

Domhnall Gleeson is an amazingly charming leading man. I was shocked how deeply he made me experience his emotional journey. He is likeable and you want to see him come out on top. Rachel McAdams is a lovely leading lady, and she possesses a kind of girl-next-door quality that makes her a perfect match for Tim. As their relationship matures you can also see her character mature, and I appreciate that depth to the performance. The other important person for the purposes of this film, and probably one of the most interesting acting performances is Tim's Dad, played by Bill Nighy. He adds such a unique twist to the story because he shares Tim's ability, so he fully understands it. There are so many knowing glances they give one another, and it adds a lot of poignancy to later scenes in the film. There are a number of other characters in Tim's life, and I don't want to short change those acting performances, but really they are mostly incidental to the main plotline. The only one that really jumped out at me, because he added a nice comedic touch was Tom Hollander as Tim's roommate. He plays a stereotypical struggling playwright who acts like he hates everything in life but actually he clearly cares about Tim in his own way.

My complaints about this film are few and far between. My biggest sticking point is that they don't fully explain how the time travel works, aside from a few cardinal rules. The execution of time travel seems a bit illogical at times, and even creates a paradox or two that they never explain. I suppose for the direction they were trying to go with the film it makes sense that they might not want to waste time explaining all the ins-and-outs, but my geeky mind wanted more specifics. I also felt the relationship between Mary and Tim escalated a bit quicker than I would expect, this is not a big deal, it just seemed a tad out of character. By and large About Time is a brilliant film with several lovely morals to the story. When I was done watching I had a broad smile on my face, and instantly started considering if I needed to purchase the film so I could watch it again and again. I imagine Tim and his Dad have actually lived several years longer than they appear because of the time travel, and it has made them quite wise. Tim is forced to learn that even the bad things in life are part of what makes us who we are so you have to be careful what you change. Then there is that final lesson that Tim spells out for us (which I won't spoil for you here) but it made me think, and reevaluate the way I live my own life. Just delightful, a high recommendation from me.

For starters, the girlfriend told me that this is one of her favorite movies so I was ok with watching it as I probably would have skipped it considering the type of movie it is. However after watching the movie I felt that this movie is highly unrated. This movie not only combines the love story you are use to seeing but also adds in a different flavor of science with time travel. I must say I found myself really loving this movie and I feel like there is nothing quite like this movie out there. The plot line wasn't anything different but instead a mixed unique flavor. The standard love story happens with boy meeting girl but the boy as it turns out is able to time travel (only in the past and all me in the family have this ability) which greatly alters not only his love life but his entire outcome. As it turns out certain events can be altered such as a child's birth, if you change things in the past. Needless to say this is a movie that is excellent for a date night and will be enjoy immensely by both parties. I would say that a weekend price ticket is easily justifiable as you will enjoy every bit of this and even find yourself laughing and tearing up at certain parts.

This is a great movie. There was so much love in this move along with comical acting. It had me in tears and laughing. It was a clean movie that I wish I would of taken the time to see in theaters. I'm gonna buy this movie!! We need more family movies like this.
I'm a sucker for time travel love stories. This one isn't terrible.

Loved it. LOVED. IT. Another instant where I strongly disagree with the jaded critics of today. What a clever, funny, sincere, heartwarming, beautifully filmed, profound, sweet, fresh, enjoyable treat this was. I think I want to see this again soon.

This is now officially among my favorite movies, which says a lot for a film with only 4 actors I even vaguely knew - 1 of whom played a small, bit part and I only recognized him due to my borderline unhealthy Harry Potter obsession. The main character, Tim, was Bill Weasley (um yes, please!) Plus Bill Nighy was there...it actually seems like they pilfered several of the Harry Potter-the-later-films-cast-members, then tossed in Rachel McAdams; which worked out just fine if you ask me.  So yeah, FABULOUS movie! My mom & I laughed like the disturbed individuals we are (well, it WAS funny!) & my dad actually stayed awake to watch the end....I can't begin to explain what a big deal that is. Add a Ben Folds song (and the other songs too) & I was in movie Heaven. I think PG-13 would have been a more appropriate rating, but maybe Kate Moss's "breasts"  (sorry, less than an A cup isn't really a breast to me, but I know she's an icon or whatever). Richard Curtis' best film, as far as I'm concerned. It's definitely not a film about time travel. It's a film about time, life, and embracing the ordinary. Time travel is simply the device used by Curtis to get us to recognise mortality, and how important it is to embrace what we have, right now. 

Clearly it is not a film for cynical people, who may be in unrewarding families and relationships. But if you have recently been faced with the mortality of you or a loved one, this film reminds you that life is short, and to love those around you while you can.

This would be a 5 star film, if the time travel had made complete sense. I suppose it's hopeless holding on to that wish, because time travel is illogical, and never will make sense.

However, "About Time" is one of the most entertaining and lovable movies I have seen in years. Featuring Brendan Gleeson's son Domhnall, as the protagonist, it displays wonderful family values, albeit those built on a section of abilities that are kept hidden from those he loves most, and people that care hugely about the people involved in their lives.

It's so un-Hollywood esque, and whereas "Love Actually" had a raunchy and sexually tense aura about it, "About Time" does not. It's so much more light-hearted. Bill Nighy is superb, Gleeson gets better as it goes, and Rachel McAdams is her usual gorgeously cutesy self. It's a delightful film, rather than a spectacular one. Perfect for a night in with a loved one.

It had moments when I was questioning where the movie was going. After seeing the deleted scenes, I had a better understanding as to why it had holes; it was too long and had to be cut. Despite that, it was real. It had real issues and real feelings. I think it will resonate more with people who have "been there" rather than those still trying to figure out where "there" is. I was relieved that the ending did not follow the bad ending films that have dominated the romance movie scene as of late. I was holding my breathe for the last 20 minutes waiting for "the bad thing" to happen to the main character(and then take the fall out for choosing yet another bad ending movie); alas, I made a good choice for Valentines Night!

Absolutely beautiful movie...one of the best I've seen in a really long time. It is not like the typical time traveler movies you've seen before (although it appears that way at the beginning). If you don't enjoy soppy films, then you should avoid About Time.
But if you enjoy well written rom-coms with a fantastic charismatic, loveable cast of characters injected with all the british charm and humour of Curtis' previous films then you're in luck.

Not sure I'm interesting in discussing movies or life for that matter with anyone who didn't like this one. Has a simple but very important message that is too easily forgotten today. Your attitude will determine 90% of your happiness in life. Something that so often gets washed way as we run from place to place in our busy lives.

About Time had some emotional highlights and character development, though I found the main character Tim to be pretty one-dimensional.  This movie was really boring and cheesy, even by romantic drama standards.  It didn't help that most of the characters were mumbling half the time.

The whole time-traveling thing was whatever, and it was weird in the sense that the time traveler inhabited his (yes, the phenomenon is sexist) former self, that day's outfit and all, so there's only one of him at any given time.  And then he can change the past (or can he?  Tim's dad said time travelers can't, but that seems to be readily contradicted by all the shit Tim does) and change the whole future as a result, without anyone else (including the other time travelers in Tim's family) noticing.  So at any given moment, Tim could be living in one of any number of timelines, since presumably all these guys could be going back in time and changing each other's lives.  Time travel is inherently a tricky thing to deal with in fiction, and it's clear that About Time didn't really care to put in the effort of making it coherent.

The ending was one of the sappiest things I've ever seen; it was like a montage of random people happily (?) going about their lives, overlaid by Tim's buoyant pep speech about how we should live each day to the fullest, blah blah blah.  I was like, WTF is this?

Oh, and this movie was pretty terrible in the family planning department.  Tim and Mary are already expecting their first child before they're married (and Tim's family applauds this, no less), and then later Tim wants a second child but Mary says no.  But Tim got his way anyway because, as Tim put it, "fortunately, we were young and careless"... uhhh, Planned Parenthood much?  Is there no birth control in the UK?  Okay, I might've misheard it as "unfortunately" (it was hard to tell), but either way, Tim and Mary should really have a listen to one of those safe sex radio ads Planned Parenthood keeps running on Oklahoma City's hip-hop radio station.  Then, some time later, it's Mary who wants another child, giving one of the worst rationales for having children ever: they need an "insurance kid" in case one kid turns out to be a genius, so then the two idiot children can keep each other company.  Because you know, there's nothing worse than having to grow up with a child prodigy sibling who wants to talk about differential calculus all the time when you just want to play with your trucks and drool all over your shirt.

Boring, uninteresting drama that squanders its potential on a bland script and disguises its limited story with the time travel aspect. The result is a film that just disappoints and you are left wanting more out of the film. I didn't like the film, and I was hoping for something considering its concept. Unfortunately, I felt it went nowhere, and instead of breaking new ground in terms of a romantic drama, it ended up being a clichéd film disguised with a neat idea. About Time may have had a chance of being a good film, unfortunately it's just an overdone predictable affair, that fails to really standout or be worth seeing. Don't expect anything good here; this is a film that will leave you disappointed. About Time is a film that just wastes a unique idea and adds every genre cliché to appeal to a wider audience. Instead of reinventing the genre, it lingers on, and navigates all too familiar territory that has been set by previous genre films. About Time is a mess, one that isn't worth seeing, and the cast here are wasted on such a bland, uninspired script that doesn't satisfy. This is a film that unfortunately is boring and has no redeeming qualities. About Time could have been a good picture, but it relies too much on predictability to create its story, that it's just not interesting in the long run. Skip it, and watch something else. This film just fails as drama, and it's a forgettable film that could have been so much more, but doesn't take off due to a not fully fleshed script, poor performances and lazy storytelling. I've seen better films than this, and About Time is a mess from start to finish, and considering some of the talent involved here, I'm in shocked that they couldn't make a better film than this.
Charming and full of sentimental moments, featuring another great performance from the beautiful Rachel McAdams

It is the kind of film that asks the viewer to invest a bit of trust in its own off the wall premise with the promise of some genuine human moments along the way. If you are willing to go along for the ride and suspend a bit of cynicism in its time travel premise (Hughes comes from a line of males in his family who all have the ability to time travel), Director Richard Curtis leads you in to some unexpected places. It's a love story and a bit or a rom com, and on a very simple and surface level it is about a young man who discovers he can travel in time and who strives to learn how to time travel from his father who went before him. Curtis uses this idea to explore some of the films more interesting ideas and creative moments. Such as the idea of treating each day as your last, or learning to live with choices that have consequences for good or bad. It is also a film about family, love, values and even innocence. When first told about his unique abilities Tim (Hughes) states that love is the most important virtue that this gift can achieve. It is not long before love represents itself as somewhat more complex and illusive than he originally thought (something that also allows love to maintain its power). It cannot be forced and it cannot be manipulated, even if you endless time to and opportunity to attempt to control it from every angle possible.

The most creative moments are interspersed, such as watching Hugh say and do the wrong thing only to quickly transport himself back and try again. Sometimes the best and most enjoyable moments lead him to exploit his gift so as to experience it again and again (in one of the more humorous moments of the film). But the film bravely uses its humor and creativity to lead us towards some genuine emotional moments. This includes an instructive piece in which Tim decides to experiment by living the same day over again without changing a thing, forcing himself to slow down and appreciate the smaller moments of our daily routines. Or when he realizes the consequences of changing one thing at the expense of another, specifically when it sacrifices a personal pleasure or desire for the sake of another. This choice really surfaces when he discovers that helping one of the most important people in his life means the life of another. 

The film isn't overly complicated. But its premise leaves plenty of room to reinvent itself as an atypical rom com. The end result is something charming, funny and challenging in its own offbeat way.  Its main stars (McAdams and Hughes) are given just enough material to leave room to experiment with their charisma, and it suits the material just fine.

Apart from that, is great writing and there is enough material to keep the storyline interesting. In some ways, it seemed more like a chick flick even though the main character was a boy. Anyway, it's worth a watch but don't expect anything different from Richard Curtis.

I'm a big fan of Richard Curtis' films (especially Love Actually). They make me feel good and are usually very entertaining. They aren't exactly the highest quality films, but they don't need to be. About Time isn't on par with Love Actually, but it is another solid entry into his overly sentimental and wholly entertaining films category. The story is a little on the cheesy side, but told well enough that you get invested in the characters who are played with charm and wit (minus Rachel McAdams, who is just there to look pretty). Bill Nighy is often hilarious and Domhnall Gleeson holds his own admirably. The overall plot structure follows its own rules when it comes to the time traveling mechanics, which is refreshing, but at times annoying too because you keep expecting established rules to take effect (like the butterfly effect) and they don't. Either way, I enjoyed this movie for what it was and am kind of sad that this might be Curtis' last film.

It's not perfectly executed, but About Time is a unique and entertaining film with a heartfelt meaning.

21 year old Tim Lake (Domhnall Gleeson) is a lonely young man.  Feeling hopeless, his life is forever changed the morning following a failed New Year's Eve Party.  His father (Bill Nighy) pulls him aside and tells him a huge secret:  the men in their family have the ability to time travel.  After he relocates to London to start a career in law, Tim puts his newly discovered gift to use, hoping to find the love of his life.  It is there that he meets the gorgeous Mary (Rachel McAdams), and Tim learns to master the time travel process to make sure things go perfectly.  However, in time, Tim discovers that making the most of life in the present is the key to happiness.  

This is the first that I've seen from Domhnall Gleeson, but I thought he was he was great in the role of Tim.  You can certainly see the awkward, lonely traits of his character and the progression that takes place during the film.  Rachel McAdams is so easy on the eyes and you can't help but to be infatuated with her as the love interest of Tim.  The supporting cast also works well, which includes the stunning Margot Robbie amongst many others.  

I was immediately sold on the concept of About Time, but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't a bit disappointed with the final result.  The chemistry between the actors is wonderful, but the film's take on the concept of time travel didn't quite meet my expectations.  There is absolutely no explanation to Tim's ability, and the scenes that demonstrate the act of traveling are underwhelming to say the least.  There are also numerous plot holes that don't correspond with the rules of Tim's gift that his father lays out at the beginning of the film.  At times, it also feels like it's getting sloppy and the run-time probably could have been trimmed by a half hour.  In spite of those issues, there is an interesting story being told with a message that did leave me thinking at the end.  As much as I wanted to LOVE this movie, I was still satisfied with its unique and interesting approach.  3 stars.

So it plays fast and loose with the elements of time travel, that's not really the point. So it's the most aggressively upper middle class thing since 'Four Weddings', that's not really the point. The point is this: 'About Time' is one of the most soppy, sincere and warm films to be produced in the last decade. It's lovely and sweet and makes people - who care to - feel happy. Some have complained that it is too full of poignant  moments and that all the crises are minor, but 'About Time' doesn't have to be 'The Butterfly Effect' simply because it contains time travel. There's no need for murder and heroin addiction; it's not supposed to be gritty, it's sentimental. Some have complained about Tim using his 'powers' to make the world work better for him and those he cares about, but the logical corollary to that is that no one should attempt to make life more pleasant for themselves and others. Seemingly these critics would prefer you do not use your 'powers' of intelligence, charm, wit, sensitivity, etc to live a happy life, but rather crash through it like some resigned misery loving toddler. Finally some have complained that it's simply ridiculous...Of course it is, it's got time travel in it! But if one is able to willingly suspend disbelief enough to take on board the one conceit, what you're left with is the sort of sincere sweetness that was evident in the most memorable parts of 'Love Actually' and which puts one in mind of 'Life is Beautiful' or 'The Eighth Day', and in my book, that is serious praise.

Ok, cards on the table moment, I am a fan of Richard Curtis's work (Boat That Rocked excepted). I especially like The Black Adder TV series, I also liked Notting Hill and Bridget Jones but I absolutely loved Love Actually. I guess you could say that I am in touch with my feminine side to the point where II can appreciate a RomCom or a chick flick for the want of a better phrase. So because of this I was looking forward to seeing About Time and whilst not terrible I really couldn't warm to it in the same way I have with the aforementioned films. My main gripe is the male lead (Domhnall Gleeson) just doesn't have enough gravitas to carry the main role and there is a painful absence of chemistry between himself and Mary (Rachel McAdams). This is almost so to the point where I was saying to myself (yes, I do actually talk to myself when watching films) "yeah, as if she would show interest in him" throughout.


Tim (Gleeson) is an average kind of teenager. The type that is not comfortable around female company (his sister Kit Kat excepted) and one new years eve his father (Bill Nighy) invites him for a quiet chat. He explains to Tim that their family are able to travel back in time. After testing this theory he decides that he is going to use it to find love but finds that whilst he can change things about his own life he cannot influence others in the way he would like. For example, he cannot "make" someone fall in love with him. What I would say is that "there are ways and there are ways Tim", none of which are either morally correct or in fact legal but I wouldn't let a minor thing like that get in the way!! Tim decides to move to London to stay with a playwright "friend" of the family who is possibly the most unfriendly man in the history of time. As you can probably guess the course of true love never runs smoothly and Tim has to go back and forth in time to attempt to correct his woeful inadequacies at just about everything from what I can see?


This is supposed to be a comedy except that it isn't really. There is the one exception of Uncle D who is a little absent minded and forgetful in the most inappropriate of ways but he is very funny and hugely likeable. The problem is that there is just not enough of him. But as ive already said the main issue is that that Mary and Tim are just not believable to me as a couple. I couldn't help but think that Curtis was whispering in McAdams ear throughout "just think back to when Ryan Gosling and Eric Bana were your love interests, imagine its them now"? In fairness to the film the underlying message is a worthy one and despite my criticisms I did think it tried to highlight our everyday woes in a positive way and its portrayal of a father and sons relationship was also very positive and one friend of mine found it moving so maybe you will too?

Domhnall Gleeson and the always shimmering Rachel McAdams have such lovely chemistry together.  It is so much more believable than any romantic chemistry I have seen onscreen in years, and yet it is simple and not forced.  But the actor who really stands out is Bill Nighy in one of his more subtle performances.  He is sweet, gentle, and genuine.  

I was surprised at how light this film is, and also how clean it is.  It's a shame that they have to throw in a few "f-bombs" to get an R rating because there really is not much else in this film other than some minor sexual talk (most of it among married couples).  It is not nearly as explicit as the nudity and blatant sexuality of Curtis's last film, "Love Actually".  This could easily have been PG-13.  

My only complaint about the film is the shaky camera effect, which fortunately is mild and not all throughout the film but is still a bit of a nuisance.  I don't even understand or like the shaky cam with action films but it is really out of place here.  

Overall this is a sweet film with some fantastic messages.  It is all about living in the moment and enjoying life, and remembering to love and keep your eyes open to opportunity.  I laughed, I cried, and I just felt warm for the two hours of this film.  Very sweet.
Heartfelt and funny.  The best of both worlds.

This movie just proves that Richard Curtis is the best at making romantic comedies. Like come on he wrote the first Bridget Jones's Diary movie, he wrote Notting Hill and he wrote and direct Love Actually. I'm a fan of all of those films and that's mostly because of Richard Curtis. His movies are always filled with enjoyable characters, funny dialogue and something that all rom coms fail to do, which is to have believable romance. I'm not a fan of a lot of rom coms, but occasionally when a director makes a good rom com, I find them pretty enjoyable to watch. For me to enjoy a rom com all you have to do as have good writing, funny jokes and believable romance. I'm not looking for beautiful cinematography, top notch visuals, compelling scores and great mood and atmosphere. Those kinds of things are for really good movies, for romantic comedies, all I want to see is good humor, good romance and good writing. So many rom coms fail at not only giving good humor, but good romance as well, which is the reason why I hate rom coms. However, when Richard Curtis is directing the film it's usually an enjoyable watch, which now brings me to his new movie About Time. About Time reminded me a lot of The Time Travelers Wife when I saw the previous, so I was a bit skeptical to see it because I really hated The Time Travelers Wife. I still gave the film a watch because I know Richard Curtis would do his best to make this film work and thankfully he succeeded at that. About Time wasn't anything special and it wasn't better then Love Actually, but the film was a lot of fun to watch. About Time had pretty decent writing, good direction, funny jokes and great chemistry between Domhnall Gleeson and Rachel McAdams. Rachel McAdams hasn't played in a good movie for quite some time now, so it was a good change of pace to see her do a good role. Domhnall Gleeson, who plays the lead character was very good in this movie, I thought it was a very smart idea casting him as the lead because he played his part very well. His character was not only funny, but really likeable and you actually gave a shit about his relationship. The supporting cast was really good in this movie as well, like Tom Hollander was hilarious in this movie, Lydia Wilson was really enjoyable to watch, Lindsay Duncan was very memorable, but of course the scene stealer in this movie was Bill Nighy. Bill Nighy is a great actor and just like his performance in Love Actually he was hilarious, fun and the best part of this movie. The writing was also good and Richard Curtis's direction was pretty solid; you can tell this is a Richard Curtis film just by the humor and the acting in this movie. I'm really glad that I enjoyed this movie as much as I did. Like I said there was nothing perfect about the film, but it was really good and I liked watching it and I can probably see myself watching it again in the future.

There are many things that I didn't like in this movie as many that I loved. Some aspects of the plot are just too in a hurry to expect most of the audience to catch it completely. The time travel is absolutely just an excuse to focus on something well far from the travel itself: relationships and decisions. Many people travels with their heart and make the proper move without caring about mistakes, appearances.. 
There's no need to travel back and forth when you know how to taste the present. To share it properly, to know when to let it go.
The acting was ok, the characters were "normal" enough to be acceptable even when some situations looked pretty "forced", but then, again, the movie was not about that.
Hope you will enjoy it as I did.

It is a tough decision for me to give this one 3 and a half stars, because it truly deserves 3 stars only, maybe my long-time admiration for Mr. Curtis' charm can add that half a star to the rating. However, after the lousy yet funky and (still) lovely "The Boat That Rocked", Mr. Curtis' tradition of sentimentalism since "Four Weddings" and "Love Actually" comes back, only with a very lesser script than its predecessors. The charming formula of Love Actually is there again, with voice-over, British-ish witty conversations (although much rarer than its predecessors), extraordinarily ordinary-life scenes for opening and ending sequences, loves without turbulences, bonding families, attached couples, mended broken hearts, and joys, many joys and happinesses. Still, the plot lacks consistency, maybe due to its sci-fi time-travelling settings, while the characters, although still charming they are, were inadequately and unimpressively depicted with an alarming lack of details and lifelikeness (which were done very, very well in "Love Actually"). Therefore, the heart-warming ending could not lift the whole film up and only reminds the audience of a typical Hollywood rom-com yet much more impressive time-travelling family film - "Click".

Richard Curtis does it agaIn. I confess that I enjoyed this film, which is fundamentally about love between people, as are all his movies. Bill Nighy has that wolfish grin that's worth watching for, and while the plot's key premise is completely implausible, with a little bit of suspended disbelief the whole enterprise becomes very pleasurable. If you never seen a British romantic comedy revolving around time travel here is your chance. A young man tries to change his past to have a better future... but doesn't work well most of the times.  Written and directed by Richard Curtis, and starring Domhnall Gleeson, Rachel McAdams and Bill Nighy, this film is like a yo-yo, it has ups and downs and it was like that until the last scene - up, down - up, down...

The plot was interesting... just imagine that your father called you at your 21st birthday, like Tim's (Domhnall Gleeson) did, and tells you that the men in his family have always had the ability to travel through time. What an opportunity! Upon learning this, Tim goes back to the night of a recent New Year's Eve party where at midnight he was too shy to kiss someone and goes for the kiss instead. Of course, when you are shy, that seemed like  logical choice!

If you don't know the author - Richard Curtis, is a New Zealand born Australian, but he was always regarded as a British screenwriter, music producer, actor and film director. He is definitely one of Britain's most successful comedy screenwriters, primarily for romantic comedy films such as Four Weddings and a Funeral, Bridget Jones's Diary, Notting Hill, and Love Actually, as well as the hit sitcoms Blackadder, Mr. Bean and The Vicar of Dibley. He is also the founder of the British charity Comic Relief along with Lenny Henry. In 2007, Curtis received the BAFTA Academy Fellowship Award, the highest award the British Film Academy can give a filmmaker. It is petty that he announced that this is likely to be his last film as director, but that he will continue in the film industry. The sad thing is that this wasn't a high quality work as most of his previous ones, but it wasn't in the bad category either. 

The chemistry of the leading couple was obvious, but some casting was questionable! Funny moments are scattered, the cute relationship all around the place, and all between were the plot holes. Film's internal logic about time travel was shockingly inadequate and unanswered, and that can put off many of the viewers. I tried to ignore those things and enjoy the comedy and the romance.  

If you like light fun and family atmosphere, interesting characters in a charming settings and unsightly pile-up of plot holes and logic problems in one movie - this could be something you'd love to see!

This film was the most wonderful, hilarious, and enjoyable movie picture that I have ever seen throughout my many years of watching films. Boring, uninteresting drama that squanders its potential on a bland script and disguises its limited story with the time travel aspect. The result is a film that just disappoints and you are left wanting more out of the film. I didn't like the film, and I was hoping for something considering its concept. Unfortunately, I felt it went nowhere, and instead of breaking new ground in terms of a romantic drama, it ended up being a clichéd film disguised with a neat idea. About Time may have had a chance of being a good film, unfortunately it's just an overdone predictable affair, that fails to really standout or be worth seeing. Don't expect anything good here; this is a film that will leave you disappointed. About Time is a film that just wastes a unique idea and adds every genre cliché to appeal to a wider audience. Instead of reinventing the genre, it lingers on, and navigates all too familiar territory that has been set by previous genre films. About Time is a mess, one that isn't worth seeing, and the cast here are wasted on such a bland, uninspired script that doesn't satisfy. This is a film that unfortunately is boring and has no redeeming qualities. About Time could have been a good picture, but it relies too much on predictability to create its story, that it's just not interesting in the long run.  Skip it, and watch something else. This film just fails as drama, and it's a forgettable film that could have been so much more, but doesn't take off due to a not fully fleshed script, poor performances and lazy storytelling. I've seen better films than this, and About Time is a mess from start to finish, and considering some of the talent involved here, I'm in shocked that they couldn't make a better film than this.

Leave your cynicism at the door because About time is a wonderful movie about love and relationships and does it perfectly. A bit of a ridiculous premise that all the males in the family can travel back in time, but it's an interesting mechanism for not only scenes full of heart but some comedic opportunities as well. The movie's pace can be a bit slow at times but if you make the investment, you'll be rewarded with a touching story surrounded by genuine performances and a positive take home message.
Gleeson nails the main character as this ordinary, dorky guy who just wants a girlfriend and to be happy with his romantic lead, McAdams, who seems to be always cast in these roles, and for good reason, because she delivers on being the loveable female lead. Each of the main characters are portrayed by actors very well. While the secondary characters are all great, each of them either funny or quirky in their own way, the person who really steals the show is Hughes, who is such an amazing actor and with his personal charisma and body language, just makes you wish you had a father like him.
As I said before, the movies about relationships and love, but with a breath of fresh air, the movie doesn't spend the entire 120 minutes focusing on the love story; it spends time on the trials and tribulations of other relationships; like Tim's relationship with his sister, his relationship with his mother, his friends and best of all, his father, who is played by Hughes. That relationship is done best of all with a scene at the end which will tug on the heart strings of even the most cynical person. Its brilliantly done and the movie's supplemented by a fantastic soundtrack mixed with pop and indie music, heightening your emotions at appropriate times.
The only minor complaint is that the plot mechanic was a bit vague and under-explained, and some characters felt like they could have been forgotten or left out, but it's only at the end you realize that the take home message was worth the entire movie. Live everyday like it's the first and last one; take time and enjoy life; don't stress yourself out or you'll miss out the best parts. The message is delivered over the course of the movie with Gleeson's narration and is expertly closed at the end which is a nod at how well the script was written.  It touched a lot of real issues like loss of loved ones, the importance of family and love; and did these themes so well.
Great story; great acting and a message that I'll take with me for the rest of my days. Live your life everyday like it's your first and last. 9/10

Um filme tocante, com uma mensagem tão pertinente para o momento: aproveitar cada dia, verdadeiramente, com as pessoas que amamos. Voltar ao tempo, para nós, não é opção, mas se fosse, talvez o resultado da equação no final também não seria satisfatório. Aprender a deixar o passado para trás, é difícil e quase sempre resistimos, mas é necessário para seguirmos adiante - e isso não é papo clichê. Eu chorei tantoooo, mas não de tristeza, foi mais como uma confirmação de que eu amo minha vida, as pessoas que fazem parte dela, e quero poder compartilhar cada instante com eles o quanto me for possível.

"We're all traveling through time together, every day of our lives. All we can do is do our best to relish this remarkable ride."

If there is someone who can get away with being too schmaltzy, generic, charming and sentimental it's Richard Curtis. It comes as no surprise here considering he's directed Love Actually, and wrote such rom-coms as Four Weddings and a Funeral, Bridget Jones's Diary, and Notting Hill among others. He has a tendency of melting even the toughest hearts and no matter how prepared you think you are for his next film somehow he gets you again. Perhaps About Time is his most sentimental film and that could turn some people off, but I must say this isn't your typical romantic comedy. Half way through the film it turns into a completely different movie becoming one about family dynamics and enjoying the ordinary moments in life. Perhaps the reason why Curtis gets away with being so charming is that he creates a perfect balance in his stories and introduces comedic relief at the right moments. About Time is a flawed film, but you can probably say this about all his films. The thing a lot of people might have a problem with specifically in this one is the time traveling element which many may find a bit absurd, but it worked for me (at least it was much better than the other time traveling movie that Rachel McAdams starred in) and I think Curtis uses this element as a sort of parable to remind us of the importance of savoring each day. It may feel like a sermon at times, but it's one I don't mind being reminded of. Carpe Diem!

Tim (Domhnall Gleeson who you may recognize as Bill Weasley in the last two Harry Potter films) is a shy kid living with his parents (Bill Nighy and Lindsay Duncan) and lovable sister Kit Kat (Lydia Wilson). The morning of his 21st birthday his father shares with him a family secret: the men in their family can travel in time, but they can only do so to moments they personally have experienced. Tim decides to use this special ability to find love, because he really needs all the help he can get for it. Tim leaves his parents beautiful beachside estate in Cornwall for London in order to become a lawyer. He moves in with one of his father's friends, Harry (Tom Hollander), who's a struggling writer with a bad temper. In London Tim meets Mary (Rachel McAdams) and the two fall for each other, but due to a time traveling incident that night is erased from Mary's memory and Tim has to find another way to win her back.

I feared this film would become another sort of 50 First Dates, but surprisingly it took an unexpected turn halfway through the film and becomes something else. It is not just a romantic comedy, it becomes a movie about family, love, and life where Tim learns a couple of valuable lessons along the way. McAdams and Gleeson shared great chemistry on screen, but the true standouts in this film were the supporting characters, especially Tim's father played by the wonderful Bill Nighy. He is great here once again, while Wilson, Duncan, and Hollander all are extremely funny and used for comedic relief. It's a relief from the schmaltzy sentimentality of the film. It's as if Curtis is admitting he's manipulated us way too much with all the emotional sentimentality and now it's time for a good laugh. If you don't find this film funny then you will probably find it way over the top with the sentimentality. It's not a film for everyone, but I had a good time and was charmed by the story.

About Time stars the Dublin actor Domhall Gleeson (Tim) and Canadian born Rachel McAdams (Mary) in a sci-fi romantic comedy that explores love and life's ironies in a somewhat long winded, overly syrupy, although, genuine manner. When Tim first discovers his ability to travel back in time the audience witnesses his learning curve; to his dismay, after he is rejected by his "first love", he quickly finds it is not as easy as he thought to manipulate others. He also realizes that tweaking his past can create ripples into his future which nearly cause him to lose his new love interest, Mary, right after their initial meeting.  Although heartfelt and well-intentioned, those (and many other) uneven and in my opinion, unnecessary, sub plots take such a long time unfolding that I must admit I near shut off my TV.
Thankfully, true love does conquer all, or maybe a handy time travelling ability does?  Well, no matter, what's important is how intensely Tim loves Mary immediately, how unbeknownst to her, he recites verbatim thoughts she had already shared with him in the future, averts her meeting the "other guy" and ensures that their "first" time is unforgettable. 
Richard Curtis's directorial mastery is revealed in his use of music and visual to powerfully create sentiment and bring it to life. The early part of Tim and Mary's deliciously sappy, but wonderfully sincere, relationship is brilliantly coupled with a colourful soundtrack and fluttering shots in the subway station that can fill anyone with glee. The beautiful scenes continue to unfold like flipping through a photo album. We watch the love-struck couple wed to Jimmy Fontana's gorgeously penetrating "Il Mondo" on a perfectly charming stormy day and begin to expand their loving family tree. Indeed the importance of a connected family unit is a fundamental motif in this movie for it ultimately serves to bring Tim to his most significant realizations and shed light on the irony that holds all life together. It is at some point between child number two and three, and after some difficult developments with Tim's father(Bill Nighy), who he is extremely close with, that he has (and we gratefully with him) an important epiphany; that no amount of changing the past can control or smooth out all the unexpected wrinkles of our lives, and neither can it ever replace letting go and experiencing the timeless now. It is the full-heartedness of the film that, although may not make us laugh out loud, fills us with lightheaded giddiness that make it irresistible.

A new funny film about love. With a bit of time travel. 

Amazing Film! Wow I'm so glad I've watch this and it caught me off guard too on how good it was. "About Time" is a romantic comedy about the vicissitudes of life and love. It's witty, clever, intelligent and very funny. But it's also a film of perhaps quite surprising depth.The performances, the screenplay, the direction and the soundtrack are first class. The humour is excellent. The film done a fine job in balancing the comedic and dramatic elements of the story, providing enough laughter and allowing it to flow smoothly without feeling too overly long despite its 2 hours running time. The message or overall theme of the film about appreciating life as if it was your last was subtle and not too forceful or preachy.The selection of songs for the film was appropriate and not too overly done for the emotional scenes.The on-screen chemistry between Rachel and Domhnall are convincing enough for the audience to watch them going through life together. On the other hand, Domhnall and Bill, as father and son, their connection is felt throughout the film and certainly evoke some poignant memories when watching them together. It's one of the best romantic comedies this year had to offer. Enjoyable movie that will lift your spirits, and you may even want to watch it again to enjoy the finer details. I recommend this movie to anyone who likes romantic comedies, or a little bit of fantasy. Do yourself a favor and go see it!!!

At the age of 21, Tim Lake (Domhnall Gleeson) discovers he can travel in time... The night after another unsatisfactory New Year party, Tim's father (Bill Nighy) tells his son that the men in his family have always had the ability to travel through time. Tim can't change history, but he can change what happens and has happened in his own life-so he decides to make his world a better place...by getting a girlfriend. Sadly, that turns out not to be as easy as you might think. Moving from the Cornwall coast to London to train as a lawyer, Tim finally meets the beautiful but insecure Mary (Rachel McAdams). They fall in love, then an unfortunate time-travel incident means he's never met her at all. So they meet for the first time again-and again-but finally, after a lot of cunning time-traveling, he wins her heart. Tim then uses his power to create the perfect romantic proposal, to save his wedding from the worst best-man speeches, to save his best friend from professional disaster and to get his pregnant wife to the hospital in time for the birth of their daughter, despite a nasty traffic jam outside Abbey Road. But as his unusual life progresses, Tim finds out that his unique gift can't save him from the sorrows and ups and downs that affect all families, everywhere. There are great limits to what time travel can achieve, and it can be dangerous too.

Richard Curtis comes back with another pleasant film, with time travel. On New Year's eve , 21-year-old Tim (Gleeson) discovers that the men in his family are able  to travel back to any time in the their past, changing things as they want.  He first uses it to go back to New Year's Eve & set an awkward interaction to right with a girl at the slaughter of midnight. After leaving the countryside for London, Tim meets Mary (McAdams), and falls in love with her. The problems of time travel soon ascend, as he tries to settle everything perfect for his family. Sooner he learns that everything can't be fixed by traveling in time, and he must obey to let some things go.

While it has many humorous moments, this is a more mature outing for Curtis, which feels a bit too grandiose in scope. The ideas are interesting, but the way they're presented seems too on the nose, even lazy at times. Of course, it is an enjoyable experience, not unlike Curtis' other work. The cast is quite good as well. Domhnall Gleeson plays a lovable klutz, nailing the comedic scenes and mustering up a soft brokenness in the more dramatic ones. (Really, he should be getting more lead roles after such a turn.) Rachel McAdams' performance is perfectly fine, even if her character feels underdeveloped, and Bill Nighy and Tom Hollander are very entertaining in their smaller roles. There are even cameos by Richard E. Grant and the late Richard Griffiths. Overall, Richard Curtis' latest is a pleasant journey, funny and touching with a solid performance from Domhnall Gleeson.

About Time transcends its rom com pedigree and asks the question: How do you live your life everyday? The awkwardly charming  Domhnal Gleeson shares some decent chemistry with Rachel McAdams, but truly shines in wonderfully comedic and sentimental moments with Bill Nighy, who plays his father.

About Time is a relaxed time travel film that puts its use into true love. It was a wonderful and heartwarming movie, but it still didn't seem to avoid some major flaws. The time travel could have used more development and explanation. The mechanics of the time travel were not well implemented in the movie thus making it confusing and very noticeable. There are also dead times where the time travel would not be used and felt like just like a regular love story, thus making the time travel a bit insignificant at times. The score and soundtrack were a bit questionable as well. Even though About Time had its faults, it did not cease to entertain me. It is a beautiful story. It could have been better if the time travel had been tweaked and fixed, but nevertheless, this movie was sweet. Flawed, but stunning. About time has its blemishes, but is truly beautiful.

Is there such a thing as a great romantic comedy?
At first I would hesitate in answering that question, there could be one somewhere I am forgetting, but I think I can confidently settle on No, there is not.  
I'm not entirely sure it is possible for a romantic comedy to be great.  At least not in terms of the grand scope of all films.  They always seem to, by their very nature, land in an uncomfortable grey area of cinema.  They lack both the heart wrenching sorrow of a true drama and the gut busting laughs of a classic comedy. They live in the realm of casual amusements, where a casual chuckle and a few less than poignant life observations are the main attraction.  
So as clear as it is that I will not be considering this film among the greats, it is about as great as a romantic comedy can hope to become.  
While nearly all films of the genre deal solely in tired clichés, About Time actually makes an attempt to venture off the beaten path.  In the typical rom-com, you know you will always have the same inevitable conflict.  After the boy meets the girl, they soon fall in love, then something happens, they break up/grow apart, and the boy has to figure out a way to win her back.  The theme of such stories being that you should fight for true love and all that good stuff.  About Time doesn't do that however, its theme is much more adult.  And as a result, far more intriguing.  
As you will know from the trailers, it is about a young man who learns that the men in his family have the ability to travel in time.  This concept alone opens up a Pandora's Box of possibilities.  Possibilities, which if explored improperly, could have greatly diminished the film.  But everything here is kept exceedingly simple.  Basic rules are established that allow for seamless back and forth travel, but only within the moments you have already experienced.  After a few cautionary tales from his father, and a kind word of advice, we set out with our protagonist on his journey to find the one thing that truly matters. Love.
I know, it all sounds very sappy.  But it is also very well done.  There are all the hallmarks of a good romantic comedy present within the story.  Moments of levity, hope, and sadness all make cameos.  But it is the message that makes this film unique and enjoyable.  You see, it isn't so much a film about love, but about finding out what is important in life.   7/10

The hands come together for Richard Curtis's latest, a Time travel romantic dramedy worth a Notting Hill of beans in a cineplex flush with superheroes and Oscar bait. Granted, you can wind your watch to writer/director Curtis' formula. His oeuvre often and rightly gets criticized for putting forth sentimental hogwash perpetrated by British archetypes. The lynchpin in this flick, however, proves to be a clever, touching, and unapologetically wonky timey wimey premise that bears a lot of fruit for moviegoers who like, well, sentimental hogwash.

In this PG-13-rated dramedy, a socially awkward young man uses his newly discovered powers of time travel to get a girlfriend (McAdams). 

Did you ever feel like Rachel McAdams earns every flick she's in an extra star? She'll only solidify that theory here. As whimsically fun and touching as Curtis' script is, her heartfelt turn makes the out-there material believable. Elevated from supporting player (see: Ron Weasley's older brother in the Harry Potter films), Domhnall Gleeson proves a risky but ultimately winning choice of everyman. Backed by Curtis veteran Bill Nighy, it doesn't take too much time to swoon for this lovelorn oddity. 

Bottom line: Love Anomaly

Time travel is one of the biggest mysteries in the whole world. Human beings keep searching for that powerful weapon to control destiny and be able to manipulate success and defeat failure. 

Movies explore this phenomenon in so many ways, travel to the past with the intention to change the future and avoid world war against machines (Terminator, Terminator 2) Travel to the past and the future in order to create a better possibilities to a family and also avoid extinction (Back to The Future and their sequels) Time travel control to avoid criminals to manipulate or alter of the past (Timecop) and even time travel in the search for a better life in a better time period( Midnight in Paris) 

In the film About Time (Richard Curtis) Time (Domhnall Gleeson) discover from his dad that the member of his family are capable to travel thru time. His father (Bill Nighty) warned him that the power to control time is delicate, also explain the consequences of doing so. Time move to London pursuing a career as a lawyer, and that's how he met Mary (Rachel McAdams)  The attraction is instant. he collect her information to call her again. Back home his landlord, a playwright  is depressed because his opening play was a disaster because his main actor forgot his lines. Time decide to go back in time to help him. Suddenly he released that he altered his future with Mary, because we never met her. After a whole series of time travels he finally was able to met Mary in the right moment and blend the present and potential future for him and Mary.

Tim, realize that you cannot change future constantly to make it perfect, without alter others destiny, from Tim sisters alcoholism, to some other family members future. 

About Time is not a great film, is just a romantic comedy, with some tone of drama. The movie explore another side of time travel, the consequences of controlling this ability, the chaos if manipulating destiny and avoid living life day by day, expecting the unexpected. That's the real message of this film. 
Life is simple, but also complex, you cannot make your life perfect, you have to enjoy it the best way possible.

I wonder what's with Rachel McAdam's and time travelers. Still, her character is lovely and different. The movie is good, it has a moral and keeps you thinking, which is a good thing. But I think there are some plot holes, like in which specific circumstances can he go back and forth. The show stealer is Tom Hollander. Oh, and there's a short scene where Tim is walking and I just wondered why on Earth they didn't get a steady cam.

Oh so googly.  From the opening strains of a favorite Ben Fold slow-jam to Mary sashaying down the aisle in a fetching red gown to Italian pop opera, this movie just charms and doesn't stop.  The filial and romantic relationships are all so supportive and honest that they made me shit Double Deckers and vomit holy thistle (UK candy and plant to parallel my usual shitting and vomiting of chocolate and daisies).  The meet-cute at one of those vogue blind restaurants is unique, and the rained out wedding scramble is so full of joy.  

I liked Domhnall Gleeson as solemn Levin in Joe Wright's "Anna Karenina," and I like him now as genial and humorous Tim.  I haven't liked Rachel McAdams since "Mean Girls," especially not after time travel/amnesia romance became her bread and butter, but her short, mousey fringe here lends her a normal, unassuming quality.

The narrative does fall apart around the middle though when the filmmakers realized they needed to inject some conflict; unfortunately, the conflict is of the high stakes but easily-fixed-by-time-travel variety.  I'm really surprised at how little the characters and the movie seem to know about time travel, theoretically.  Does Tim not figure out that if he goes back in time to help his playwright lessor Harry that he forfeits his chance of meeting Mary?  If Kit Kat possesses new memories of being in love with Jay, why doesn't Tim have new memories of the baby boy?  The audience is expected to just roll with his rejection of a living, breathing child because the world of this movie is Tim's, not anyone else's who may have developed strong attachments to this kid, so he's just free to play God, as it were.  It's more than a little unsettling once you think about it.  The sperm explanation doesn't make any sense at all; Tim still risks making changes every day he goes back to relive the pleasures of a day.

All in all, the romcom parts are sweet and quirky, but the time travel conceit just goes to prove a trite thesis:  the best time is now.
This movie is excellent.  It is funny, has great acting, and is beautifully filmed.  But most importantly, it carries a strong message about life that we all need to hear.

The night after another unsatisfactory New Year party, Tim's father tells his son that the men in his family have always had the ability to travel through time. Tim can't change history, but he can change what happens and has happened in his own life-so he decides to make his world a better place...by getting a girlfriend. Sadly, that turns out not to be as easy as you might think.
Avoids being too sweet, this light and warm slice of romantic comedy adds a scoop of science fiction to make it more interesting.

It's your run-of-the-mill romance with a touch of sci-fi, and overall it's another solid effort by UK's Working Title. While the gimmick of time travel itself quickly wore off and the element of it clearly had some holes in it, About Time proves to be a lovely, heartwarming story about love, family and living your life to the fullest, which eatily benefited from having a rising talent Domhnall Gleeson and a rom-com veteran Rachel McAdams in front, with the formidable support of the likes of Bill Nighy, Lindsay Duncan and many more. If you have some innocence, or the desire for it left somewhere in your heart, this film will hit too close to home like you've never expected; in the end, everybody wins.

Upon turning 21, Tim(Domhnall Gleeson) gets The Talk from his father(Bill Nighy).  No, not that one.  The one about the men of their family all being time travelers.  Tim is naturally skeptical until he takes a test run and undoes an embarrassing moment at a New Year's Eve party.  However, that trick does him no good with Charlotte(Margot Robbie).  But then it turns out he may not need time travel after all to find love when he meets Mary(Rachel McAdams) which would be considered love at first sight if it did not happen in a blacked out restaurant.

"About Time" does have certain things going for it such as a totally relatable couple for a change and showing everybody the right way to do a musical montage sequence.  But like Richard Curtis' previous film, the bloated, if entertaining, "Love, Actually," he again proves his willingness to overstuff a romantic comedy to the brim.  This time, he adds time travel into the mix but except for one strange detail does not do anything original with it, as Tim seems content to stalk in the fourth dimension.  That's not to mention the whole business with Tim saving Harry's(Tom Hollander) play being so contrived, since Harry is such a pompous jackass that the Dalai Lama would not even help him.  For the record, that sort of is par for the course in "About Time" whose central message is that women can only find true happiness in the most boring man possible, as Tim's dad uses time travel to catch up on his reading.

However, that film was a much better film than this one. Some scenes felt like copies of scenes from other films like the overflow of rain on the wedding tent (seen in Betsy's Wedding) and the date at the restaurant where everyone can't see each other (seen in When In Rome).

Domhnall Gleeson is ok as Tim. He reminds me a lot of Harry Potter's Rupert Grint. He portrays Tim as clumsy at times. He lacks the charm that Hugh Grant and Bill Murray have. This is the 3rd time travel film that Rachel McAdams has been in (Time Traveler's Wife, Midnight in Paris). She and Gleeson, in my opinion, didn't have a good on screen chemistry. I think another actress in that role would have done a better job, example: Kiera Knightly or Rosamund Pike.  Bill Nighy steals the film as Tim's father. He is the best thing about this film.

A surprisingly charming and witty film.  I was honestly not expecting so many humorous moments.  I also was impressed that the typical love story format was largely ignored.  I always tire of seeing man and woman fall in love, man and woman fight and break up, man and woman reconcile and live happily ever after.  Thankfully, none of those stereotypical formats exist here.  In fact, the movie is largely based on one man's love for multiple family members, not the least of which is his father.  It's a time travel movie less concerned about the trivial aspects of the concept, rather the importance of telling a good story.

Riddled with charm, but lacking in feeling, 'About Time' seemed more like a waste of time in the end. 
One golden rule with time travel is that the less you explain the more likely it is to work. You don't want to give people enough to pick holes in your plot. While this film left a lot unexplained with its time travel aspect, it also began to fall apart as time went on. The few rules that were established were ignored by the end. And some concepts didn't even make sense from the start.

Richard Curtis is a master at making great British dramedies. This is by far his best, its filled with so much heart and has many, many laughs. Tim's father tells him that the men in his family can travel through time and well he uses that power to find himself a girlfriend. He's awkward and quite frankly has no luck what so ever with the opposite sex. I loved the way the movie opened with him describing his family and the routine they go through and how he just loves his family to death.

Then he finds out about his powers and uses them for stuff like kissing a girl and not making himself look like a total fool. Then the humor becomes a huge part when he moves in with playwright Harry, literally everything that comes out of his mouth is just pure comic genius. Then he meets Mary played by the adorable and just plain wonderful actress Rachel McAdams. He instantly falls in love with her and a relationship forms and we watch and its beautiful. Never has there been a movie so unrealistic with time travel but almost incredibly realistic with relationships and love.

But then it goes from being about using time travel to craft the perfect relationship from being about moving on in life and being okay with who you are and appreciating what you've got. That's where it got really emotional. A big point is about the relationship with his father and how they are so close and I think that's a great thing to put in so a lot of people can relate to.

Overall this is the best movie of the year so far and has great performances, good humor and an amazing relatable and heartfelt story that should have a lot of people falling in love with this movie. This is a true romantic, funny dramatic masterpiece.

Grade: A+

It is hard to imagine a more contrived plot device: For some reason, all the men in Tim Lake's family (Domhnall Gleeson) acquire the ability to go back in time on their 21st birthday and relive (or change) events in the past.  But it is easy to suspend belief in this amiable comedy with its winning cast, that includes Rachel McAdams as his love interest Mary and Bill Nighy as the father.  While an underlying message of Richard Curtis' earlier (and superior) Love Actually was to live each day to the fullest, this movie telegraphs it.  Still, a nice way to spend a couple of hours with someone you love.
